desc: Gentle touring trip through open pastureland.
directions: Take the A482 Aberaeron to Lampeter road, turning off on the B4342 to reach the putin in Llangeitho.

desc: Good training run. Watch out for 4 weirs just upstream of the A487 bridge in Aberaeron, can be portaged river right if necessary. Take out in the harbour on one of the slipways.
directions: The takeout is at Aberaeron harbour. Get to the putin by heading inland up the A482, then take a small road down to a bridge over the river once you reach Cilau Aeron.

desc: Playful run that doesn't require massive rain to be running. Watch out for the weirs in high flows, the towbacks can be dangerous at high levels.
directions: A4107 and B4286 Port Talbot to Treorchy roads

section: Llanfihangel Glyn Myfyr to A5 road bridge
desc: A mixed bag: some excellent rapids but also a few nasty fences and weirs. Watch out for a nasty weir where a footbridge crosses the river after the Cierw has joined.
directions: Putin from the B5015 at Llanfihangel Glyn Myfyr, and takeout at the A5 roadbridge at Plas Isaf.

desc: Grade 2/3 rapids interspersed with broken weirs.
directions: Both putin and takeout are just off the A474 Ammanford to Brynamman road. The takeout is in Ammanford itself, and the putin is just west of Glanaman.

desc: Reputedly has a series of large grade 5 falls, but little information is available. The stream itself runs through Gwaun-Cae-Gurwen to join the Aman, and doesn't itself have a name.
Good steep fun, but usually full of trees.
directions: Turn off the A470 to the village of Aberangell and follow a steep road up out of the village until you get to the river. Putin as the river nears the road at a phonebox and bridge.

desc: An adventurous day out with a walkin to the putin. The drops tend to be grouped: a flurry of steeper drops, a breather, then another flurry. The section around the Snowdon railway bridge is grade 5+, and includes Llanberis Falls.
directions: Head up a steep road beside Llanberis Snowdon railway station that runs near the track. Keep going as far as possible until continuing on foot.

desc: Artle Beck starts with a bang - a cheeky drop immediately after the put-in. The river then makes its way into a steep sided gorge with more fun grade 3 rapids. Beware of trees throughout and a deer fence just above Gresgarth Hall. Just next to the hall is the biggest drop on the river - a large bowl shaped weir.
directions: From Caton, head eastwards towards Brookhouse and turn left up the hill. Follow the road all the way to Crossgill, parking just over the far side of the bridge in a convenient bay, big enough to hold 3 or 4 cars.

desc: Supposedly England's shortest river! The main rapids of interest are the falls in Bainbridge.
Tree infested spate trib of the Tees, with one harder fall. Difficult to predict water levels due to relying on the Hury dam to release, but generally only goes after heavy rain.
directions:
Drive up to Hury Reservoir and put on below the dam. Obviously do not attempt to paddle down the dam overspill, which in no way resembles a big kayak slide.
Get out at the confluence with the Tees in Cotherstone, where there's convenient parking down a small track signposted "to the river."

desc: Good touring or beginners trip.
directions: Putin at the A458 bridge at Llanfair Caereinion. To get to the takeout head north to Meiford on the A495 and head down a small road to a bridge over the river.

desc:
A fun spate ditch with a continuous feel. Grade 2/3 at the start leads into woodland. The river picks up after a km or so leading to a series of slabs near some footbridges. Keep your eyes pealed for trees and the crux rapids which most will portage and all will if there's still trees in them. These consist of one large fall, a big slide into a boily pool, followed by another big slide.

Once clear of the woods there are series of sheep fences to be ducked and some more grade 3 rapids through the village. Beware the last drop which is a small slot funnelling river right which will hold a boat and swimmer. The take out is 200m on the left after this.
directions: Drive through the village of Barbon up the valley. The road crosses a stream and parking can be found on the left near a footbridge. Take out just west of Barbon where there is a big layby just before the A683 on river left.

desc: Unusual and undemanding run: mediocre whitewater but fun as an exploratory adventure. First 500m often portaged along the footpath river left to avoid 2 sheep fences, before continuous gd2 through open moorland. Landacre bridge is an alternative takeout as it is flat from there down to Withypool.
directions: Putin at the small bridge in Simonsbath, and takeout at the main bridge in Withypool. Lanacre bridge bridge is a possible alternative takeout (a few km upstream of Withypool) as it is flat from here down.

desc: Flat at first before gradually building in difficulty to a long rapid leading down to Tarr Steps.
directions: Putin at the main bridge in Withypool. Takeout at the ford at Tarr Steps: this can be reached either by heading south down minor roads river right through Hawkridge, or river left through Liscombe.

section: Shap Wells Hotel to Scout Green
desc: Wave trains and wire fences combined with one big fall (Docker Force).
directions: Either do this as a continuation of Wasdale Beck, or put in at Shap Wells Hotel. Get out at Scout Green, or continue on low grade water for 3km to the Lune confluence near Tebay.

desc: The harder rapids are all concentrated at the top of this rarely run river. To avoid the harder rapids and enjoy an alpine style (read steep and fast) grade 3 run, put in at the footbridge 1km downstream from the put-in.
directions: Whilst the forestry-track to the put-in is physically drivable, the road is not open for public access so it is recommended to park in the large parking area just downstream of Blengdale Bridge and man-up for the walk-in. You'll have driven past Wellington Bridge at the takeout on the way up the valley.

desc: Trees portages can be annoying, but lower half is fun.
directions: Putin at Clapper Bridge on the small road a km downstream from the village of North Bovey. Takeout at Drakeford Bridge, on the small road south of Lustleigh.

desc: A series of three waterfalls, below Gibson's Cave (a 30ft fall onto rock!), only paddleable in spate.
directions: Park in the nature reserve signposted from Bowlees and inspect the falls from the car park. Flushimere Beck has also been paddled above Gibson's Cave from high up on the moors.

desc: Fun Usk trib, somewhat marred by the number of fences strung across the river that are awkward to portage. The top of the run is fairly mellow, best bit is a series of ledge drops near the end.
directions: Takeout is at Llandovery on the A40. To get to the putin head upstream towards Buith Wells on the A483 and access the river at Cynghardy.

section: Mary Jones cottage to Dysynni confluence
desc: If you're feeling adventurous you can start with a 5m fall just above the described putin. A series of good grade 3 rapids lead down under the road bridge, which mellow to the odd grade 2 as you head down to the takeout.
directions: Head up towards Llanfihangel-y-Pennant from the B4405 as it passes through Abergynolwyn. Putin and takeout at the road bridges either side of the village.

desc: Gentle touring section.
directions: From the A490 Welshpool to Llanfyllin road, turn up the B4393 and take the first small left to the putin at a small bridge. To get to the takeout continue along the B4393 through Llanfechain until the road crosses the river again. Takeout here, or at the main A495 road bridge further down.

desc: Lots of water is needed for this upper section of the Calder and it rises an falls incredibly quickly. If the river looks brown and churning at Calder Bridge, and it's still raining, you might be in luck! The river starts as a narrow flume ride down little more than a stream, before dropping through a couple of tight gorges. Once past Monks Bridge the river changes in character and some more powerful grade 3/4 rapids lead to a 2-tier slide. A couple hundred meters of easier water leads to the confluence with Worm Gill (beware of the sheep fence). Either take out here, or continue down the easier (and now much bigger) lower section of the river to Calder Bridge, or the sea.
directions: To reach the put-in, drive north from Calder Bridge towards Ennerdale Bridge. As the Cold Fell road takes a sharp left hand turn, park up and walk the <1km eastwards to the river. Takeout at Thornholme Farm

desc: Good touring run: apart from a few fences and weirs it is grade 1 for its entire length.
directions: Take a small road heading east off the A490 just south of Chirbury to reach the putin at a bridge over the river. The takeout is at the bridge on the small road between Forden and Caerhowel, or alternatively you can continue down onto the Severn.

section: Roman fort bridge to Irfon confluence
desc: A pleasant beginner's run, and makes a good alternative start for the lower Irfon.
directions: Putin at the A483 bridge over the river just west of Garth. Takeout just before the confluence with the Irfon at the bridge in Llangammarch Wells.

desc: Decent grade 2 run, with a couple of weirs.
directions: Take a small road off the A470 just north of Clatter to reach the put-in bridge. Takeout just above the Severn confluence at the B4569 road brideg near Caersws.

desc: Pleasant stream, can be used as a alternative start for the Dee.
directions: The takeout is in the village of Llandrillo on the B4401. To reach the putin head upstream for about 3km to Pennant Bridge.

desc: Good paddle, one weir to watch out for just before the village of Glyn Ceiriog.
directions: Take a small road off the B4500 about a km upstream of Pandy, this leads down to the putin with parking. Takeout at a small bridge off the B4500 just before reaching Chirk.

desc: A few frustrating fences and weirs that slow you down, but otherwise good gd3 run.
directions: Putin at a bridge over the river just off the B4500 just upstream of Chirk. To reach the takeout cross the A5 and follow small roads to the bridge over the river just before the confluence.

section: Carreg Cennen Castle to Tywi confluence
desc: Always a battle through trees and fences, you'll probably only paddle this once.
directions: Reach the putin by heading towards Carreg Cennen Castle from the A483 just south of Llandeilo, there is a small bridge over the river after you pass the castle. Takeout at the closest small bridge over the river to the A483.

desc: Obscure spate ditch in Kielder Forest. The Seven Linns section is a series of falls and slides. Other notable features are Cat Linns and Jerry's Linn (a 4m fall).
directions: You need to get the OS map out and get familiar with forestry tracks! The Seven Linns, which are a few hundred metres long are the main event and it's debatable as to whether it's worth paddling the rest of the beck, or just going to Jerry's Linn for a one-hit wonder.

desc: The top section consists of a series of hard falls and slides, before levelling off to grade 3/4 through Coniston and down to the lake.
directions: Follow the road/track upstream from Coniston for about 2km to the mines. Take out either in Coniston or on the lake.

desc: A fun little river: there is a single grade 4 drop between two footbridges as you paddle through the Builth Wells golf course.
directions: Turn north off the a483 in the village of Cilmery near Builth Wells; keep heading right and you will reach a small bridge over the river. The takeout is back in Cilmery near the railway tracks. It is also possible to continue joining the Irfon and soon the wye to takeout in Builth itself.

section: Pentre'r Felin to Park Farm bridge
desc: Spate tributary of the Usk: a fun torrent.
directions: Putin in the village of Pentre'r Felin just north of Sennybridge. It is easiest to paddle onto the Usk and takeout at bridge just off the A40.

desc: Relaxed 1.5km of flat from the dam down to the first (big) fall that most will portage. Easy grade 3 follows until a hard double drop immediately below a footbridge perched between two boulders. Grade 3/4 from this drop down to the takeout.
directions: Head up to the Claerwen Reservoir (through Elan Village) from the A470 at Rhayader. The takeout is at a small bridge at the head of Caban-Coch Reservoir, and the putin is just below the Dam at the foot of Claerwen Reservoir itself.

desc: Good touring river, with Llawhaden as a lunch-stop or an alternative takeout to shorten the trip. The only potential nasty to watch out for is the weir just below Canasten bridge. Avoid the low tide if going all the way down to Landshipping as the last km can get shallow.
directions: To reach the putin turn west off the A478 at Llandissilo village and follow the road to a bridge over the river. The takeout is in the estuary at Landshipping (drop south off the A40 along the A4075, then head west along small roads to the village).

desc: Hard fast run, excellent adventure.
directions: Takeout in Resolven either at the confluence with the Neath or somewhere in the village. To get to the putin stay on river right and head upstream on small roads -- keeping right you will end up in a gravel area with plenty of room to park.

section: Pont Clydach to Church Road bridge
desc: Excellent spate paddle, fast and furious. Requires a walk-in and out and the best putin/takeout depends on the levels: scout round the A4096 bridge and see what you fancy taking on.
directions: The run is based around the A4069 Pont Clydach bridge between Llangadog and Brynamman. From here you can walk upstream into the Foel Fawr quarries to find a good putin as far up as you have time for. Paddle down under the bridge and the easiest takeout is on river right just before the wooded section where there is a footpath back up to the road. It is possible to keep going further downstream and simply walk back up the river bank.

section: Clydach Gorge Park to River Usk
desc: Fast-paced narrow tree-lined run. Trees in or across the river are often an issue. After 1.5km there is a waterfall under a footbridge (grade 5). Keep your eyes peeled as this comes up fast round a RH bend. Next interesting feature is a 50m tunnel: there is nothing significant in the tunnel itself but a decent exit rapid at the end which you commit to by entering the tunnel. Take this exit rapid roughly centre and then be prepared to hop out on river right to inspect and possibly portage the slot drop that follows it. In higher flows it is a good idea to scout this exit rapid by parking at the bridge over the canal on the way out of Gilwern, walking up the canal towpath for 200m until you can scramble down to the river on the right. From this point all that remains before joining the Usk are a couple of 1.5m weirs.
directions: Just west of Abergavenny take a small turn off the A465 opposite Gilwern village. 300m up the road there is a small carpark on the right next to the river. Takeout after you've joined the Usk, the first bridge after the confluence is on a small road linking Gilwern back to the A40.

desc: Slightly sadistic paddle: lots of awkward drops, trees in nasty places, etc.
directions: Putin at the B4416 roadbridge just off the A470 east of Dolgellau. Takeout at the small road bridge just before the confluence with the Wnion.

section: Country Park bridge to B5130 bridge
desc: Starts well, but has been used as a rubbish tip downstream. And then you paddle pass the sewage works. Not inspiring.
directions: Putin at the bridge in the country park just south of Wrexham (on Sontley Hill road). Takeout at the B5130 bridge between Sesswick and Isycoed.

desc: A pleasant touring run, most excitement in the top half before the confluence with the Llugwy.
directions: Putin at the A470 road bridge just outside Betws-y-Coed. To reach the takeout head downstream along the A470 past Llanrwst then take a small road towards Dolgarrog that crosses the river at the confluence with the Afon Ddu.

desc: A fairly constant gradient, makes this fast moving in high water, but beware of trees.
A spate beck with an excellent continuous gorge nestled between easier sections.
directions: Park on side of road where the Pennine Way crosses the Malham/Arncliffe road. Only really room for one vehicle. Walk downhill for approx 100 metres, through gate and across fields towards the beck. Put on as soon as there's enough water to float. Take out at the road bridge in Arncliffe.

desc: Good fun with an impressive gradient. Lots of few tree portages and other nasties, including "Fairy Falls"; not top quality paddling, but an interesting bash.
directions: From Llanrwst on the A470 head to the village of Trefriw along the B5106. The takeout is just upstream of the village above Bro Geirionnydd weir (near the large greenhouses). To reach the putin head up the small steep road towards Llyn Crafnant, either putin at the lake itself or at a small stone hut about 2.5km up the road.

desc: Good intermediate paddle, with a lively gorge to finish off the trip.
directions: Turn off the A4067 out 2km downstream of the cray reservoir and follow small roads back up towards the reservoir to reach a small bridge. There is not much space to park here. Takeout at the Usk in Sennybridge: take the turning into the Army barracks and then head down a small road just to the right of the barracks next to the river.

desc: A series of four waterfalls. The first is a big 10m straight drop into a big plunge pool. The second is a twisty double drop consisting of two 1.5/2m falls. The third is 4m and should only be run in high water. The last drop is a simple river wide 1.5m high ledge. The beck then levels out until you join the Eden.
directions: Either walk up the side of the beck as part of an Eden trip or find the beck next to Nunnery Walks in Staffield.

desc: Short and sweet Tawe trib, good if you have extra time after the Tawe.
directions: Takeout in the village of Cilmaengwyn, just before the river sumps under the canal. To reach the putin head upstream through an estate and once you've gone as far as you can continue to walkin for 10 minutes or so until you reach a 4m fall.

section: Rhigos slag heap to Glyn Neath
desc: Unusual run: paddle through the guts of a slag heap, 4m drop onto rock, three amphitheatre-shaped falls...
directions: Takeout at the main road bridge over the river Neath in Glyn-Neath (just off the A465). To find the putin head up small roads away from Glyn-Neath towards Rhigos slag heap. Putin a small road bridge as the river runs into the slag heap itself.

desc: Pretty much continuous grade 2 with some 3. Keep your eyes out for possible tree/fence portages. Hop out at the A470 bridge as the difficulty ups a little and it's worth inspecting the next 500m for trees. Down to the viaduct there's some slides, a slot then a sweet double drop into a slot rapid into a clean 4ft drop. Get out at the viaduct as there's sumps and nastiness if you choose to continue.
directions: Takeout at the viaduct just after the A470 roadbridge (just south of Ffestiniog). A footpath river left leads back to the road. To reach the put-in, head upstream along the road on river right to Cwm Farm.

desc: A pleasant touring river through wooded banks.
directions: Takeout in St Clears at the smaller bridge downstream of the main A40 bridge. To reach the putin head upstream along small roads to the village of Gellywen, either putin at the bridge here or head up the road on river left from which you can access the river a little higher up.

desc: A pleasant run with a few weirs to watch out for. Although the surroundings are certainly not idyllic, the last 2km in particular is good water. Takeout after the confluence with the Taff.
directions: This is a busy valley! Putin at the small bridge just off the A4059 upstream of Mountain Ash. Takeout after the confluence with the Taff from a layby on river right just downstream of Abercynon.

desc: Makes sure to get on below the hard fall at the putin. A series of small weirs lead down to the confluence with the Dee (or it is possible to walk down a footpath river right). Once on the Dee, a fast and flat touring paddle.
directions: Putin where the B4391 crosses the Hilant river which flows into the Dee. There is a grade 5 falls about 200m downstream of this bridge so make sure you walk downstream and putin below this! It is also possible to putin at the bridge over the Dee as it flows out of Bala lake. Takeout at the B4401 road bridge.

desc: A gentle touring section.
directions: Putin where the B4402 crosses the river just south of Llandderfel. Takeout at the small road bridge just outside Corwen, it is the first bridge downstream of the main A5 road bridge. Alternatively, use the A5 road bridge itself.

desc: Pleasant section ending in the historic Trevor rocks.
directions: Putin from the carpark on river left just downstream of the main bridge in Llangollen (just below the weir). To reach the takeout head downstream along the A5 and turn off towards Trevor (B5434) at Froncysyllte. The takeout is where this road crosses the river at a narrow bridge.

desc: An excellent touring section, just a couple of weirs to watch out for in the last 2km of the run.
directions: Putin at the B5434 narrow road bridge over the river just outside Trevor. Takeout at the pub next to the A528 road bridge between Erbistock and Overton.

desc: A touring section, very flat but quite pretty.
directions: Putin at the pub next to the A528 road bridge between Erbistock and Overton. Takeout in Bangor-is-y-Coed at the narrow bridge just downstream of the main A525 road bridge.

desc: Pleasant flat touring paddle, forming the border between England and Wales for much of its length.
directions: Putin at the narrow road bridge in the village of Farndon (just downstream of where the A534 crosses the river). There are various possible takeouts in Chester.

desc: Masochistic. Mellow for the first 1.5km, then suddenly drops steeply through quarry workings. Watch out for the river disappearing underground: carry up river right past the quarry buildings to where it re-surfaces. This happens again later. Once you reach the footbridge (an alternative putin) you've braved the worst, and the river eases to grade 4.
directions: Putin at Delford Bridge, the bridge downstream of the village of Bradford. Takeout at the bridge at Tregaddick just upstream of the confluence with the river Camel.

desc: A fairly low grade river, which is generally only paddled in spate due to the reservoir holding back the water. The main interest is from small bouldery rapids, weirs and a couple of small falls at the end. Trees may be problematic.
Technical stuff for the first few hundred metres, before droping back with only a 6ft horseshoe weir about 2/3 of the way down to worry about.
directions: Head for Juniper, where it's possible to put on either of the two major tribs, although fences could be an issue. Instead put on at Peth Foot. Take out at the A695 road bridge.

desc: Hard beck with lots of falls and tight rapids in a closed-in gorge. At least one portage. Inspect the whole thing before paddling - spate levels would probably be suicide!
directions: Follow Oddie's Lane up the hill and park near the farm after it flattens out. Take the footpath down to the beck.

desc: A fun wilderness adventure. The river is mostly pooldrop grade 3/4, but there are 2 waterfalls in the middle.
directions: A long shuttle that probably requires an OS map. Takeout at "junction pool" at the confluence with the Tywi between Ystradffin and Rhandirmwyn. The putin is at a small bridge as far upstream as possible which is difficult to find.

desc: Short but always interesting, is usually combined with the section above or below.
directions: This is usually combined with the section above or below, but can be paddled on its own. Putin (or continue) at Hall Dunnerdale Bridge, and takeout at the bridge just south of Ulpha (or continue downstream).

desc: The run starts as a fun grade 3, but after the main road bridge begins to gorge up. Trees are usually a problem, and it can be difficult to stop and portage. The hardest drop is the last drop in the gorge just before the takeout. If you want to avoid the harder bits, it is possible to takeout at the A458 road bridge.
directions: Takeout at the A470 road bridge just north of Mallwyd. To reach the putin head upstream along the A458 crossing from river left to river right. Take a small road towards Tafolog to a bridge where you can get on.

desc: Painful. Although there are some good drops if the water is high enough, this is a tree-infested ditch.
directions: Takeout at the B4520 bridge at Llanddewi'r Cwm (or continue down to the confluence with the Wye). Get on at a small stream trib at Penllech.

desc: A fun duck-n-dive paddle. Expect lots of trees, mixed with plenty of grade 3 gorge enclosed drops.
directions: Takeout at the war memorial in Llanwrda just upstream of the A40/A482 junction. To reach the putin head upstream along the A482, and get on at the fifth bridge across the river.

desc: Starts off as bouncy gd2 and gradually gets harder before the river narrows into Tylwch gorge. Excellent grade 4 for the next km with a flourish at the end. The last km is back to bouncy gd3 to the takeout.
directions: Takeout at the A470 bridge just south of Llanidloes. To reach the putin head out of Llanidloes on the B4518 to a small road bridge at Tylwch.

section: Abergynolwyn to the old Bryncrug road bridge
desc: An easy run, but depending on levels some of the weirs may be nasty. Watch out for wires across the river.
directions: Putin at Cwmcarn, heading down to a bridge over the river by turning off the A467 at a roundabout. Takeout just south of the M4, next to Ebbw Bridge roundabout in Maes-Glas.

section: Pont y Grible to Pont ar Eden
desc: A narrow continuous run through the Coed Brenin forest. No nasties although there is usually some woodwork to sneak around at some point.
directions: Takeout at the public toilets in Ganllwyd, from here there is easy access down the bank to the river. To reach the putin head north along the A470, then take a small left turn just before Bronaber down to a bridge over the river. Alternatively, head into Coed y Brenin across the river and you can access the river from their main carpark.

desc: Great bouncy run when you have good water. No real nasties, the hardest drop is Llanedw Falls just below a metal footbridge.
directions: Takeout at the B4567 road bridge just before the confluence with the Wye. Putin at a small road bridge just north of Cregina.

desc: A small steep and twisty spate trib of the Tees. There's a tight gorge after ~1km, which is quite continuous and contains a surprise slot.
directions:
Drive through Eggleston on the B6278, following the river on the left. Take the left turn which crosses the river at Middle End Farm and put on here.
Either take out at the small road bridge above Eggleston, or carry on down into the Tees.

section: Ennerdale Water to Wath Brow Bridge
desc: The top two kilometers from the lake to Ennerdale Bridge don't contain much white water (except for two weirs, the second of which may require inspection, as the river leaves the lake). However they do contain lots of trees. If you can find anywhere to access the river in Ennerdale Bridge itself, this may be a better bet if you're not a confident tree dodger.
directions: Carry up to the lake from the public car park at the western end of Ennerdale Water. Follow the road alongside the river until you cross a hump-backed bridge just outside of Cleator Moor. There is a fair sized area you can park at, right next to the river.

desc: Hard and serious, but excellent. Takeout just above Furnace Falls.
directions: Takeout at the A487 bridge at Furnace. To reach the putin head up a small steep road along river left until it crosses the river.

desc: Rarely paddled hard spate trib of the Yorkshire Esk. Falls, slides and rapids abound in this short gem.
directions: Put in near the Station in Goathland. Get out at the confluence with west Beck at Beck Hole.

desc: Gentle touring river.
directions: Putin just off the A4119 just north of Ynysmaerdy (heading north, take the first exit at the 3rd roundabout after passing the Royal Glamorgan Hospital). There are various takeout options near Cardiff, and it is possible to paddle all the way to Cardiff Bay. The takeout recommended here is at the road bridge in St Fagans, about a km downstream of the A4232 road bridge.

desc: A beautiful run with a hidden gorge.
directions: Both putin and takeout are a bit tricky. Takeout at the footbridge in the middle of the caravan park between Glanwern and Upper Borth, and the use the public footpath to wherever you managed to park your vehicle. The putin at the A487 bridge at Tal-yBont is also difficult, it may be worth changing before you get there.

desc: Radical steep trib into Lake Vyrnwy.
directions: Takeout at the B4393 bridge next to Lake Vyrnwy. To reach the putin head up the small road on river left towards Llyn Efyrnwy. The road runs near the river all the way up to the lake, so pick a suitable spot to putin along the way.

desc: Pleasant run, with a fun tunnel under the motorway.
directions: Putin at the bridge just of the A473 in Pencoed just north of the M4. If you're coming along the M4, exit at junction 35. Takeout at Ogmore castle just before the sewage works and confluence of the Ogmore. Be careful as the castle carpark is occasionally flooded by high tides.

desc: Putin below Bolham weir, as it is usually nasty. Down to Tiverton are numerous small rapids and weirs. Takeout on river left just downstream of Bickleigh weir.
directions: Putin at Bolham weir, about 2km north of Tiverton on the A386. Takeout at the road bridge near Bickleigh, where there's a nice pub near the weir.

section: Stokes Wood to Haven Bank Quay
desc: Flat apart from weirs: this is one to save for low water when nothing else is running. When higher, you'll just portage round a series of hideous towbacks.
directions: Takeout at Haven Bank Quay in Exeter, parking near the AS Watersports shop (EX2 8GX). To putin, park at Stokes Wood carpark, just north of Exeter on the A386. From the carpark, carry your boats further along the road and then down a track to the river just upstream of the railway bridge.

desc: Extremely steep continuous series of slides and falls in Grizedale Forest.
directions: It's on the road between Spark Bridge and Hawkeshead. Put on at the bridge above Force Mills, take out next to the phone box in Force Forge.

desc: An easy run through a beautiful gorge.
directions: Takeout at the A458 bridge over the Banwy at Llanerfyl. To reach the putin head west along smaller roads to the 2nd bridge from the Gam/Banwy confluence.

desc: Steep, low volume with an unrelenting gradient: slightly bonkers. Scout the run on the walkin and then run the bits that take your fancy. The usual putin is in the middle of a two-tier fall about a km from the road (the larger first tier has a practically non-existent landing and is barely ever run). Note that it is possible to start higher up, if you're looking for an adventure!
directions: Park by Public Toilet Falls on the Mawdach. The Gamlan joins just downstream so walk down the road to the bridge and then walkin up river left. The usual putin is at a two tier fall about 1km upstream, takeout at the confluence.

section: Braich y Cymmer to Ogmore confluence
desc: Easy and pretty, but filled with trees, low bridges, low wires and fences.
directions: Takeout at the main bridge in Brynmenyn. Head upstream along the A4064 and take the second bridge across to river left and carry on upstream for another km or so to a small bridge near the sewage works.

desc:
This starts with a dog leg drop and waterfall. 100m downstream is 'Edge Of World Rapid' - a hard pin ball toboggan drop.
More steep grade 3-4 rapids lead you to the next tricky drop known as Underworld. A further km of grade 3/4 rapids and the river opens up before reaching Glenridding village.
directions: Follow Greenside Lane up to the youth hostel from Glenridding Village and put on near here. Take out in the village itself.

desc: A serious undertaking.
directions: Takeout at the confluence with the Teigl where there is a footpath out to the road. Head upstream along the A496 and get on at a small bridge off the main road as soon as it comes back to the river. If you head up higher than this there is a really nasty drop under the next bridge upstream.

desc: A fairly mellow river, with some low grade shingle rapids and one harder drop on a bend at grade 3.
directions: Put in river right from the road bridge on the A65, following the footpath to the river. There's a car park opposite this. Get out river right at Greta Bridge near Wrayton where the A687 and A 683 meet. Parking available on the verges.

desc: A fun slabby run that only comes up occasionally.
directions: Putin just underneath the exit dam from Grwyne Fawr reservoir. Takeout onto a footpath at the confluence with the Grwyne Fechan or simply continue down to the main A40 road bridge.

desc: A flat and fast run. Watch out for low bridges.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Pontyberem, parking in the carpark on river left upstream of the bridge. Takeout at Pont Newydd, where there are two impossibly low bridges. This is just east of Carway and downstream of Pontyates, where the disused railway crosses the river.

desc: Beautiful little river with fun narrow gorges. No nasties, the long tunnel under the motorway holds no unpleasant surprises.
directions: Putin at the small ford just downstream of the M4/A48 junction (take the A48 south parallel to the M4, then take the first small right under the M4 to the river). Takeout at the Hendy Rugby Club near the A4138 bridge in Hendy.

desc: Fun little river, despite the closeness to the road you soon get lost in the little gorges. A few weirs, but nothing nasty.
directions: Putin at a small bridge just off the A40 (or at the A40 bridge itself) just upstream of the village of Halfway. Takeout at the A4069 bridge just south of Llandovery before the confluence with the Tywi (Towy).

section: Cader car park to Abergwynant main road bridge
desc: A tough little stream that drains off the flanks of Cader Idris. The hardest section of the river is downstream from the Kings YH (the 2nd half), with the top half a gd3/4 warm-up. Watch out for a nasty weir about 200m upstream of the takeout bridge.
directions: Takeout at the A493 road bridge near Abergwynant. To reach the putin follow a small road upstream. About 2km upstream (after crossing from river right to river left) are two bridges off the road at the Kings Youth Hostel, it is possible to putin here if you wish. Alternatively carry on looping away and then back to the river (keep going left!) to the Ty Nant carpark and picnic spot.

desc: A mixed bag. From Llyn Y Gader to Llyn Cwellyn is a scrappy gd 4, but then it's a slog across the lake (you can takeout at the start of the lake and just do this top section though). The section from Llyn Cwellyn to Waunfawr is unremarkable gd2 mostly, but there is a nice gd4 drop at Betws Garmon.
directions: Takeout at either of the two A4085 road bridges (the lower one being near Waunfawr). Putin on Llyn Y Gader, the smaller lake after Llyn Cwellyn as you continue upstream along the A4085.

desc: Outstanding run that is rarely in condition. Requires a 2.5km walkin up the left bank so you can scout the river on the way in. Putin just below a large waterfall: Scwd Ddu (the Black Waterfall). Takeout at above the bridge in Glyntawe, as their is nasty fence just below.
directions: Park somewhere near the A4067 bridge at Glyntawe (there's also a smaller bridge just downstream that may be easier to park near). From here you need to walk the boats in up the footpath on river left. Keep going for 2.5km until you reach the plungepool of a large waterfall.

section: Bryn Cul farm to Dinas Rock
desc: An alternative start for the Mellte that requires a short walkin to reach. A difficult run with a number of waterfalls. Watch out for a number of gorge sections that often end in something nasty/impossible. In general river right is best for scouting/portaging. You join the Mellte about halfway down, and continue down to the normal Mellte takeout at Dinas Rock carpark.
directions: Park at a layby on the A4059 north of Penderyn (just north of a cattle grid next to a rpivate road that heads towards a farmhouse near the river). From here walkin to the river along a footpath, don't use the private road. There is an alternative footpath in from Penderyn itself, but you miss out on the top bit of the run. The takeout is at a large carpark by a small stone bridge that you'll reach if you keep driving through the Pontneddfechan towards the river (east).

desc: Very continuous spate beck, few eddies and one large fall (6m) which many will portage.
directions:
Access is from a layby on the A6024 with a small path leading west to the river (about 300m). Put on the river as far up as water levels allow.

Take out above the old road bridge at Hayden Bridge where there are a few small laybys.

desc: What might have been a good grade 2 run is marred by lots of fences, and a nasty weir near Stanton.
directions: Takeout at the small road bridge just off the A465 Abergavenny to Hereford road, just north of Pandy. To reach the putin head upstream along small roads towards Llanthony, and get on at one of the bridges over the river before you get there.

desc: Constant gradient flume-type run: great fun but challenging at the grade (nothing hard, just continuous).
directions: Takeout just upstream of West Luccombe. Keep heading up the steepest lanes until reaching the putin at the highest road access.

desc: An unusual Tees spate trib, which starts off flat before some gorge sections, a big slide and a rocky 3m fall.
directions:
In high water, drive up either side of the valley and put on where the road crosses the Beck. Otherwise drive up the small track which follows the Beck to the North of Middleton-in-Teesdale and put on as high up as you like.
Get out above the Middleton Bridge on the Tees.

desc: Pleasant touring section with no nasties.
directions: Putin at the A483 bridge in Llanwrtyd Wells. Takeout at the B4519 bridge (just off the A483) near Garth, or if you want to make the run 4km shorter use the bridge in Llangammarch Wells.

desc: Watch out for the weir just after the railway bridge about halfway down.
directions: Putin at a small bridge just off the A483 north of Llanbister. If you want to cut the trip shorter, it is possible to get on at the A483 road bridge downstream. To reach the takeout head south down the A483 to Llandrindod Wells. The takeout is at a small footbridge (Shakey Bridge) next to the road directly east of Llandrindod Wells, it can be tricky to find so an OS map is helpful.

desc: 2km of easier water leads down to the highlight: Alpine bridge gorge and the following km of gd2/3. Below here the river is flatter with occasional gd1/2 rapids. Takeout just before the Wye confluence at the obvious old railway bridge on river right. A 5min walk from here takes you to a small road.
directions: Putin at Shakey bridge, a small footbridge next to the road directly east of Llandrindod Wells, it can be tricky to find so an OS map is helpful. Takeout at the small road on river right at the Wye confluence, it is possible to walk down to the river from the road.

section: Cefnhirfarwr bridge to B4580 road bridge
desc: Good fun continuous grade 2/3 run.
directions: Takeout at the B4396 bridge just before the confluence with Afon Tanat (just east of Llanrhaeadr ym Mochnant). Putin at the 3rd road bridge upstream along a minor road just before a steep hill.

desc: Awesome spate beck, despite the walk-in! Starting from Black moss pot, (a slot drop with a nasty towback), there's a couple more hard rapids, followed by a long section of grade 2/3. The fairy glen and Galleny Force (~4m drop) make up the lower, very continuous section, with long technical slides and excellent challenging rapids in a gorge.
directions: Drive up the track from Stonethwaite and park at the campsite, then follow the path up as high as you can be bothered, inspecting en route. Get out when you return to the campsite.

desc: Fun continuous but easy spate run. Watch out for fences on the way down.
directions: Takeout at the A494 road bridge just before the river meets the lake. Putin at the small bridge in Parc, it's a bit tight and probably worth changing before you get there.

desc: An adventurous run. Walkin from the takeout up the path on river left to just above or below a large gd5 fall. The run is fairly easy down to a weir, and hots up as the trees close in. Much of the last km is pretty sketchy.
directions: Takeout is just east of Bethesda at a small road bridge over the river. From here walkin up the path on river left.

section: Blaenau Dolwyddelan to Pont y Pant
desc: The value of the run is few good feature drops in the top half of the run. After these the river opens out and meanders down to the takeout at Pont-y-Pant bridge.
directions: Takeout at Pont-y-Pant bridge, just off the A470 by a restaurant near Pont-y-Pant rail station. To reach the takeout head upstream along the A470 and turn down a small road just west of Dolwyddelan. Continue along this road for about 2km to the second bridge over the river.

desc: Good introduction to moving water for beginners which finishes with a flourish through Jim's bridge.
directions: Putin by parking along the road near Plas-y-Brenin near Capel Curig and walk the boats down a footpath to the end of the lake. The takeout is down the A5 towards Betws-y-Coed, take a small track opposite an Esso Garage to reach Jim's bridge.

desc: Mostly unremarkable gd1 with a few fences to portage. Highlight is 3 partially natural weir drops that can have good holes in high water.
directions: Putin from the A479 bridge just west of Talgarth (just off the A438 near Bronllys Hospital). Takeout just above the A438 bridge in Glasbury on river left.

desc: The top section is fast but tree-infested, but soon turns into a pleasant touring paddle. Watch out for a 8m waterfall about 5km down just below a small bridge over the river (inspect from the footpath on river left).
directions: Takeout at the main road bridge in Pontardulais, just before the confluence with the Gwili. Putin at the bridge about a km upstream of Dre-fach. The top section can be tree-infested and there are a number of small bridges further downstream if you want to shorten the trip.

desc: An excellent run. Watch out for a trees and one small weir, but otherwise no nasties. One harder fall (gd4) jsut before the confluence with the Tawe is easy to spot with an obvious horizon line.
directions: Takeout from the Tawe at small road bridge just upstream of the M4 about a km below the confluence in Clydach town. An OS map is useful to find the putin as its tricky: head upstream along minor roads on river right and then head down to a small bridge by Penlanau.

desc: Excellent steep continuous paddle, watch out for trees and a wire across the river.
directions: This flows into the Ogwen at Bethesda from the south-west. Putin at a small bridge at the top of a steep road up to Mynydd Llandegai. Takeout at the small reservoir, a tunnel downstream makes proceeding to the Ogwen not worthwhile.

section: Gilfach y Rhiw bridge to Pont Marteg
desc: A grade 3 run, but is usually paddled for its well-known one-hit wonder grade 5 gorge.
directions: Takeout at picnic spot just upstream of the A470 bridge on river right (on the road between Llangurig and Rhayader). To reach the putin head upstream on river right until you can turn down to the river at Gilfach-y-Rhiw.

desc: A pleasant touring paddle. The run will be easier on an outgoing tide but this is not essential.
directions: Takeout in the carpark river left downstream of Penmaenpool toll bridge (connecting the A493 and A496). Reach the putin by heading upstream along the river left bank from the A470 past Cymmer Abbey. Get in about 3km above the Abbey as the road comes close to the river.

desc: A beautiful meandering run, with a couple of weirs to watch out for.
directions: Takeout at a small footbridge just before the great Corras bends: this can be reached by heading down river left along small roads from the B4347 bridge at Kentchurch. Takeout at the large carpark between Monnow Street bridge and the B4293 bridge in Monmouth.

section: Fron Fraith Hall bridge to Abermule
desc: A lovely short gd2 paddle, with a couple of sloping weirs that might get sticky in high water.
directions: Takeout at the B4368 bridge in Abermule, or paddle down into the Severn. Putin at a small bridge off the B4365 just downstream of the Llenmerewig turn-off.

desc: A nasty start as you have to portage 3 or 4 riverwide hanging fences in the first 200m but after this the river is a good run with the best bit being a good series of ledges that can have quite sticky holes in high water.
directions: Takeout in Aberbran at a small stone bridge just before the confluence with the Usk. To reach the putin keep heading upstream along the small road on river left to a bridge at Tir-y-Felin.

desc: A one-hit wonder grade 4 gorge, but worth the walkin. Works well combined with the Giedd.
directions: Takeout at the bridge just about the confluence with the Giedd, although because the run is so short is it usually better to combine it with the Giedd. It is easiest to simply walk up river left to putin above the gorge, although it is possible to drive up along the small road.

desc: Fast but easy spate run, with 2 harder falls. There are few eddies, with the first gd4 as the river steepens into a RH bend, dropping into a mini-gorge. The 2nd gd4 is 200m downstream.
directions: Takeout at a footbridge at the outskirts of Brynamman on a footpath just off the road. To reach the putin head north along the A4069, find somwhere to park and then walk down the grassy bank to the river.

desc: Excellent stream run, with a few good gorges.
directions: Takeout in Cwm-twrch Uchaf (on the A4068) at the minor road bridge just before the confluence with the Twrch. To reach the putin head upstream from river left and cut down to the river from the road where you can just north of Bryngrunin.

desc: Fun in a painful way. The hardest drop is fall onto rock, and some barbed wire dodging is required.
directions: Takeout next to the A4067 bridge over the Tawe just north of Glyntawe. Putin from a large layby off the A4067 a few km upstream from where you can walk down to the river.

desc: Fast and fiercely continuous spate ditch across a featureless moor. About 1km into the run is a harder slot-like drop, inspect river right: be careful as there are few eddies and little warning. After this the river eases until a weir just before the takeout.
directions: Putin at the layby by the junction of A4086/A498 at the eastern foot of Llanberis Pass. Takeout at the first lake you reach heading towards Capel Curig from the putin.

desc: Some decent whitewater with lots of (mostly friendly) weirs. In high water makes a good playrun.
directions: Putin and takeout are just off the A465: takeout at the B4242 bridge in Resolven; putin at the Dinas Rock carpark in Glynneath, be careful not to leave valuables in your car.

desc: A very rarely run spate trib of the upper South Tyne with several waterfalls including one very tricky 3m slide into 5m drop with a shallow landing!
directions: It's possible to paddle from Nenthead, but is flat until the put-in on the road bridge where the B6294 crosses the river. Get out in Alston, or continue down the South Tyne.

desc: Popular classic near Fort William, super fun. Putin just below the unpaddleable Steall Gorge below or above "Boulder Blast": a long chaotic rapid. Then down to the sticky Dave's Hole, before feeding into Scimitar Gorge, 3 tricky drops in quick succession. The fun continues: Mad Mile, Leg Breaker, Dead Sheep falls. Polldubh Falls at the takeout is the largest waterfall, a relatively straight-forward climax to a great run.
directions: From the north A82 roundabout in Fort William head off towards Glen Nevis. The takeout at Polldubh Falls is obvious, where the road first crosses from river left to river right. To reach the putin keep heading upstream to the end of the road. To reach the putin at Boulder Blast rapid, walkin along the path to Steall Meadows. After 400m as you cross a side stream turn off on a small path that leads down to the river.

desc: Fairly continuous spate beck, mostly grade 3 with three harder rapids/falls.
directions: Put in at the road bridge in Little Town, where there is parking. Take out at the road bridge in Stair, where parking can be found a short walk away.

desc: Mostly shallow and slow, due to the reservoirs restricting the flow, the main interest on the Nidd comes from weirs.
A beautiful little river with no nasties.
directions: Takeout at the main bridge on the outskirts of Newport before reaching Newport Sands. To reach the putin head east along the A487 and turn off onto small roads to stay south of the river (just before the bridge at Felindre Farchog). Putin at the bridge over the Afon Brynberian, a little trib.

section: Ogwen Bank to Scout Hut Bridge
desc: The run starts with a bang with Ogwen Bank Falls (gd5) followed immediately by the Gun Barrel. From here the water is easier but fun down to the scout hut bridge.
directions: Putin at Ogwen Bank, just off the A5 south of Besthesda. Takeout at small bridge just off the A5 heading to Tregarth, or continue downstream onto the harder section that follows.

desc: The classic section of the Ogwen, and the hardest. A superb continuous run with no particular nasties. Can be scary in full spate.
directions: Putin at the small bridge upstream of the main A5 road bridge, or get-in at Ogwen Bank if you have time to paddle the top section too. Takeout at the A5 bridge, there is limited parking so if you have time continue onto the next section downstream.

desc: The river needs to be at least bank full, at such levels it will be a fun run with plenty of trees to dodge and a couple of weirs.
directions: Putin just downstream of the tunnel under the B4564 at Evanstown. Takeout at the small bridge off the A4093 at Blackmill.

section: Ramshaw Fell to South Tyne Confluence
desc: A rarely paddleable spate trib of the South Tyne with a couple of 2m+ falls and fast flowing rapids.
Fun spate run, watch out for low fences.
directions: Takeout just downstream of the confluence with the Afan in Pontrhydyfen at a footbridge next to the B4286. To reach the putin head north through Tonmawr and continue up the road along the river right bank until reaching a small bridge.

desc: A small, tight, continuous spate beck with a number of falls, two of which are quite tricky.
directions: Follow the road between Halton Gill and Stainforth and put on where you see the resurgence after a cattle grid. Take out either at the confluence, or continue on down the Skirfare.

desc: Spate stream with 4 brilliant gorges. There is harder gd4 drop about halfway down after the 2nd gorge, and a series of steps below the bridge in Trawsfynydd can be gd4 in big water, watch out for sticky stoppers.
directions: Takeout at the lower road bridge in Trawsfynydd, and putin at the A4212 road bridge at Pont Dolydd Prysor.

desc: Adventurous run. Starts with 500m of gd3/4 down to a wooden footbridge. Be careful as you enter the gorge that follows as a few hundred metres downstream is Scwd Einion Gam, a 25m waterfall directly at the end of steep closed-in gd4 rapid. A difficult portage on river left. Fun water follows in the spectacular gorge, watch out for Gladys Fall another waterfall that is usually portaged. Continue past the confluence to catch the tail-end of the Nedd Fechan.
directions: Takeout at the small bridge in Pontneddfechan, at the start of the "waterfall walk". Heading north onto the A4109 you need to walk the boats down the first forestry track on the right (with a green gate). 500m down this track is a bridge over the river.

desc: At suitable levels for the gorge the first 3km will be a flat scrape. The gorge itself is tough, and much probably still hasn't been paddled. A km above the Doethie confluence the river eases back to gd3/4 before the takeout at Junction Pool (Towy confluence).
directions: Takeout at "junction pool" at the confluence with the Tywi between Ystradffin and Rhandirmwyn. An OS map would be useful to find the putin via small roads from Llanddewi Brefi.

desc: Bonkers, hard and exciting run with an arduous walkin. Make sure you takeout above Aber waterfall.
directions: Drive upstream from Abergwyngregyn along small roads as far as you can and then continue on foot. Climb up past Aber Falls, the takeout for this section is just upstream, and continue upriver as far as you wish.

desc: Reasonable gd4/5 run to reward the 2km walkin. Watch out for trees.
directions: Turn off the A55 at Abergwyngregyn and head upstream to the takeout bridge at Bont Newydd. From here walkin 2km along the path on river right to get on just below Aber Falls.

desc: Totally bonkers. Take ropes, abseil harnesses, torches and start early.
directions: Putin at the A44 bridge at Ponterwyd. Takeout at a small footbridge downstream of Devil's Bridge Pontarfynach that can be approached from downstream along the road running along river right.

desc: Pleasant run. Watch out for the concrete ford in the caravan park in Pant-y-Ffrid, the hole can be sticky. The harder rapid is at the end, just above the bridge in Berriew.
directions: Putin at the caravan park just off the B4390 in Manafon (ask permission!). Takeout at the main bridge in Berriew.

desc: Good run, even if a little litter-filled. Watch out for a few low pipes over the river.
directions: Putin at the minor road bridge between Wattstown and Pontygwaith. It is possible to takeout at the confluence with the Rhondda Fawr in Porth, or continue another 5km along the lower section of the Rhondda Fawr to Hopkinstown.

desc: A more relaxed paddle than the upper section. A few weirs to watch out for, but nothing serious.
directions: Takeout in Llanbradach, find a convenient route down to the river from estate next to the A469 bridge. Takeout at one of the many road bridges towards the estuary. If you want a shorter trip, there are plenty of bridges all the way down.

section: Low Sweden Bridge to Scandale Bridge
desc: Short Beck near Ambleside with two 3m+ falls and a series of tricky rapids.
Grade 2/3 leads down to the Mount Severn weir. This is a bit tricky, falling steeply onto rock and then funnelling through a slot, but can be portaged easily.
directions: Takeout in Llanidloes, just downstream of the main bridge on river right. To reach the putin head up minor roads on river left through Glan-y-nant to the bridge at Old Hall.

desc: Unremarkable run, but pleasant enough.
directions: Putin at Llanidloes, just downstream of the main bridge on river left. Takeout in Caersws at the football ground just before the railway bridge.

desc: Pleasant touring run, although this is not a pretty section. Watch out for Penarth weir 3km east of Newtown. This obvious from the river and can either be portaged well before round the weir buildings on river left, or scramble up the steep right bank just above it.
directions: Putin at Caersws on river right at the football ground just before the railway bridge. Takeout at the bridge in Abermule. It is easy to shorten the trip if necessary, but the bottom half is probably better than the top half, so if you do simply putin somewhere downstream of Caersws.

desc: A pleasant touring section: there are a few weirs but most will be friendly unless the river is high.
directions: Putin at the main bridge in Abermule. Takeout in Pool Quay on the A483 just north of Welshpool, or at Buttington on the A458 (3km earlier).

desc: The bore is a tidal phenomena that happens twice a day. The incoming tide forces a pressure wave to go roaring upstream. The EA publishes a bore forecast for the year giving dates and times: the best bores are usually on big spring tides.
directions: Various combinations are possible, don't forget you will be surfing/paddling up- rather than downstream with the tide. You can try to stay with the bore by going from Newnham to Minsterworth, or from Minsterworth to Gloucester. To stay on the wave the best bet is to do a series of short surfs and keep overtaking the wave again in a car. For example: get on at Newnham and surf to Broad Oak (2km), then drive to the Severn Bore Pub jump back on and surf the 3km to Minsterworth: you will have around 50 minutes to do the shuttle.

desc: Grade 2 interspersed with small broken weirs. One weir just after the A472 is larger and a possible portage.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Argoed, just north of Blackwood/Coed Duod on the A4048. Takeout at Wattsville, just upstream of Risca: take a small road swinging back down to river left just downstream of the A467 bridge.

desc: A high water trib of the Wharfe, with some grade three rapids and the odd fence to dodge.
directions: Put in at Halton Gill where the bridge crosses the river. Take out at the Arncliffe bridge or continue down into the Wharfe.

desc: Steep section of the Sprint near its source. A series of rocky continuous slides and small falls.
directions: Drive to the head of Longsleddale and either risk your car's suspension 2km up the track past Sadgill, or walk in. Put on at the confluence of the two streams near the end of the track, and take out when you've had enough!

desc: Tidal playspot at the southern side of a tunnel under the A5 road barrage. Requires a good spring tide, you need to get there about 2hrs before high tide at Holyhead.
directions: Park at the eastern end of the A5 crossing and paddle in along the southern side (a nasty hole can form in the tunnel and you have to paddle through the gap if you paddle in along the northern bank).

desc: Very hard, crunchy waterfall spate beck. Various falls, some with shallow landings. Trees may mean some are portages. There's also a big sloping weir in Brough.
directions: Get in on the stream off the B6276. Get out on the right after the weir in Brough.

section: Trebanog Isaf to Mellte confluence Dinas Rock
desc: You get on just below a tunnel, and grade 2/3 water leads down to a 3m waterfall with a shallow landing. The best section is shortly downstream as you paddle under a wooden footbridge, and ends in a 10m gorge. As the river flatterns out and you paddle past a big cave on river right watch out for the boulder choke downstream. An awkward portage on river left that requires a rope.
directions: Takeout at the confluence with the Mellte at a large carpark by a small stone bridge that you'll reach driving east towards the river through Pontneddfechan. Putin at a layby off the A465, this is only accessible when travelling eastbound along the A465, just before it crosses the river.

desc: Excellent touring run. Watch out for trees.
directions: Putin at the minor road bridge in Login: an OS map is useful to help find it. Takeout at the old bridge in Whitland, just downstream of the main B4328 bridge, or if you want a longer section continue downstream onto the next section to Laugharne.

desc: A pleasant mostly-tidal touring section, often combined with the section above.
directions: Putin at the old bridge in Whitland, just downstream of the main B4328 bridge, or combine this with the section above. Takeout at the main carpark in Laugharne.

desc: Entertaining grade 2/3 with some good playspots. Be careful around Quaker's Yard (just upstream of Abercynon): there is tricky grade 4+ drop which is followed by two weirs that can be nasty at higher levels.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Aberfan just off the A470. Takeout at the northern outskirts Pontypridd somewhere along the road running along the river right bank just upstream from the A4223 bridge.

desc: Pleasant paddle: mostly flat with a series of weirs some of which may need to be portaged.
directions: Putin at the northern outskirts Pontypridd somewhere along the road running along the river right bank just upstream from the A4223 bridge. There are plenty of possible takeouts through Cardiff. There is a large carpark opposite the castle at the sports institute, or continue all the way down into Cardiff Bay.

desc: Fun run of ledges, shoots and narrow gorges.
directions: Putin at one of the two bridges below Pontsticill reservoir in Pontsticill itself. Takeout at Tefechan at the outskirts of Merthyr, parking in the layby at the A465 road bridge. It is possible to continue downstream further into Merthyr if you wish, there are plenty of possible takeouts in town.

desc: Mostly flat, with a few small weirs. A decent touring run.
directions: Putin 300m upstream of Greystone Bridge (SE of Launceston, near the village of Little Comfort). There is a small unmarked track down to the putin on river right, but limited parking. Takeout at Horsebridge just upstream of Luckett.

desc: Fun touring section. Watch out for 2 large weirs that need inspection (on river left is easiest for both).
directions: Putin at Horsebridge (just upstream of Luckett). Takeout on river right just downstream on of the main road bridge at Gunnislake (on a quite lane just off the main road).

desc: A beautiful touring river. If you continue below the recommended takeout there are two large weirs before the confluence with the Vyrnwy that are good playspots in medium water but get nasty in higher levels.
directions: Putin at a footbridge at the entrance to a caravan park off the B4391 just downstream of Llangtnog. Takeout in Llanyblodwel (just west of Poarth-y-waen) at a lay-by just upstream of the bridge, or from the pub carpark.

section: Old Glanrhyd Bridge to Usk confluence
desc: Fun run. Watch out for a steep 1m weir about halfway down, and the hardest drop is a sticky slot near the end, just underneath a bridge off the A470 to the industrial estate.
directions: Takeout at the outskirts of Brecon at the minor bridge just downstream of the A40 bridge. Putin at Old Glanrhyd: head upstream along the A470 from Brecon and take a minor road on the left immediately after the RH A4215 turn-off.

desc: An interesting diversion from the Duddon. A hard slide/slot at the put-in leads into a continuous gorge section and a final rocky fall, before levelling out as the beck joins the main river. A good giggle.
directions: As you drive through Seathwaite up the valley you'll see Tarn beck on your left. Park up next to the stone wall and put on as high as the water level/value of your boat allows. Take out after the final fall by the footbridge, or combine with a run of the lower Duddon.

section: Smiddy Well Rigg to Tarset Burn Confluence
desc: A short Kielder Burn with a walk in and a couple of small falls.
Trees usually a problem, East Okement is much better.
directions: To reach the putin park in Belstone and then walk-in along the track heading upstream out of the village. Takeout around the village of Sticklepath.

desc: Watch out for the large sloping weir about a km below the putin.
directions: Putin on river right at the confluence with the Twrch (between Ystragynlais and Ystalyfera). To reach the takeout head into Swansea along the A4067 from junction 45 on the M4. At the next junction take the sliproad up the the roundabout and take the 2nd exit as if to return the A4067 but instead take the small road off to the right part way down the sliproad from where you can access the river.

desc: Silly waterfall/slide/rocky ditch. Has only seen a handful of descents.
directions: Turn off the B6277 at Langdon Beck (~ 8km north of High Force) onto a minor road signposted to Cow Green reservoir. Park at the reservoir and walk-in 3km to the dam. The falls are just below the dam.

desc: A relaxed run with occasional grade 2/3 rapids. Watch out for a weir at the bridge just upstream of Llangeler, it can be nasty at high levels. 3km below this weir is the hardest drop, the grade 3+ Henllan Falls.
directions: Putin just above or below the grade 3 drop at the bridge in Maesycrygiau, along minor roads just north-west of Llanllwni. Takeout on river right at the carpark by the rugby ground in Newcastle Emlyn, just upstream of the main bridge along the A475.

desc: A gentle flat run, with one harder rapid Cenarth Falls that are often park'n'hucked on their own.
directions: Putin on river right at the carpark by the rugby ground in Newcastle Emlyn, just upstream of the main bridge along the A475. Takeout at the carpark on river right in Cardigan, downstream of both bridges.

desc: A steep narrow run with two distinct gorges, the 2nd of which is only possible in medium levels. Trees are usually a problem.
directions: Takeout at the lay-by by the A496 bridge just north of Pont Tal-y-bont. Putin at disused bridge next to the A470 bridge near Pont y Pandy.

desc: Fast, frantic and fun: eases off after the weir.
directions: Takeout at Chagford Bridge, just north of Chagford itself. To reach the putin head upstream along the minor road south of the river: at the last sharp left bend before the road end take the steep footpath down to the river. It is possible to putin 2.5km higher by continuing to Batworthy at the end of the road and walking in over the hill.

desc: A collection of weirs (some of which are playable) and one small fall.
directions: Put on above the weir in Etal Village. Take out on the right at Twizel Bridge.

desc: A relaxed touring run with a few weirs to watch out for.
directions: Putin at Hele bridge, the A386 roadbridge just north of Hatherleigh. Takeout at Rothern bridge, the minor bridge just downstream of the A386 roadbridge to the north-west of Great Torrington.

desc: Gentle warm-up leads to a fast and commiting gorge section that is often plagued by trees.
directions: Putin at a layby just downstream of Church Bridge, the A592 bridge just south of Limefitt Park campsite. Takeout river left just downstream of the A591 road bridge behind the garage.

desc: A short and playful section, the classic low-water option for North Wales, and site of the national whitewater centre. Watch out for rafts, this is a busy section of water.
directions: Between Bala and Llyn Celyn along the A4212 take the signposted turn into the the national whitewater centre. This is takeout. Either simply walk up and run the best bottom section repeatedly, or you can drive up the small road to a large carpark to putin just below the Dam.

desc: A good run, especially when combined with the upper section. The harder drop is Bala Mill Falls just before the takeout on river right.
directions: Between Bala and Llyn Celyn along the A4212 take the signposted turn into the the national whitewater centre, and putin at the bottom of the harder upper section, or continue up the Dam for a full run. Takeout in the main carpark in Bala just doenstream of the A494 bridge on river right.

desc: Fast and bouncy in big water; lots of weirs. At lost levels, all the weirs are runnable, the biggest being a sloping weir directly under the bridge in Ystalyfera. This is a possible takeout, or continue downstream to the Tawe confluence.
directions: Putin in Ystradowen at a bridge down a small road off the A4068 just south of Cwmllynfell. Takeout in Ystalyfera, either at the bridge with the large weir underneath, or further downstream at the confluence with the Tawe.

desc: A fun grade 3 run for almost it's entire length, with a harder 500m gorge just above the takeout. The final gorge can be inspected from the path on river right.
directions: Putin just off the A470 at Llanbrymair. Take the turn-off towards Tafolwern at the S-bend in the A470 and get on at the first bridge over the Afon Laen (its confluence with the Twymyn is just downstream). Takeout at the A470 road bridge near Glantwymyn (next to the A470/A489 roundabout); its a bit awkward but you can scramble up the steep bank on river left. Alternatively continue down to the B4404 bridge over the Dyfi.

desc: The rapid under the bridge in Llandovery can reach grade 3 in high water, but otherwise a relaxed and pleasant grade 2 touring run.
directions: Putin at Dolauhirion, the minor road bridge just upstream of the main A40 bridge in Llandovery. Takeout at the bridge downstream of the Llandeilo A483 bridge, on a minor road between Llangathen and Golden Grove. It is possible to takeout in Llandeilo to shorten the run by 5km, but access to the river is tricky.

desc: An easy touring run through beautiful countryside, with the opportunity to stop at a castle.
directions: Putin at the bridge downstream of the Llandeilo A483 bridge, on a minor road between Llangathen and Golden Grove. Takeout upstream of Carmarthen before the Gwili confluence: follow the B4300 out of Carmarthen along river left and access the river from a layby near Wenallt.

desc: An excellent spate stream: continuously hard paddling. Watch out for the grade 6 fall, just after a bridge: this has been run but only in big flood, most will portage river left. There is a boxed in weir just above Pontardawe which is sketchy in big flood, portage right if necessary. Takeout just above the tunnel in town.
directions: Takeout in Pontardawe at the lower of the two A474 bridges: there is a carpark just upstream of the bridge on river right. Putin at the northern outskirts of Rhyd-y-fro: a small road (Barans Road) heads off the A474 and crosses the river at a bridge. Alternatively take the RH turn further up to a bridge over the Afon Egel.

desc: A pleasant touring run with a few small weirs to negotiate.
directions: Easy to make shorter or longer as desired. Putin at the A4077 bridge at Crickhowell, at the meadows in Abergavenny, or any of the bridges down to Usk. The takeout at Newbridge can be made conveniently straight into the pub beer garden on river right (with permission!), or it is possible to continue downstream even as far as Caerleon.

desc: Pleasant touring section, plenty of alternative takeouts if you want to cut it shorter.
directions: Putin at the A490 bridge. Various takeouts are possible along the way to the confluence with the Severn depending on the length desired: marked here is the B4380 bridge at Montford Bridge just upstream of the confluence.

desc: There's a 2m fall along this run, but beware of fences.

section: Wasdale Bridge to Shap Wells Hotel
desc: A continuous and steep spate beck, with a few falls and nasty weir, finishing with an 8m tiered drop.
directions: Put in off the A6 north of Kendal. Either get out at the hotel, or combine with Birk Beck down to the Lune.

desc: A dam release river maintained by the Yorkshire branch of Canoe England. Releases are published on the YORCIE website in advance and modest payment is required to paddle. The river features have been improved to produce a number of surfable waves and one larger weir drop. The eddies are small and hard to catch, so a swim maybe a long one!
directions: Drive up the road from Blubberhouses and turn right down the single track to the bottom of the dam and large parking area. Either do laps of the upper section by walking back up, or continue down to Blubberhouses, using the car park above Fewston reservoir.

section: Capel Hermon to Copper Mine carpark
desc: Tree filled ditch: should be a good grade 3/4 run but trees in all the drops usually spoil it.
directions: To reach the river take the minor road just off across the Mawddach just downstream of Public Toilet Falls (in Ganllwyd). The takeout is at the carpark just downstream of the first bridge you reach after the Mawddach. Putin about 4km upstream at the bridge at Capel Hermon.

desc: Mid-grade spate beck with weirs and one interesting 4m fall.
directions: Follow A686 past Whitfield, turn left for Nenthead is seen, follow road till a bridge over the river is crossed. Park in layby on right for the get in. Take out is at Cupola Bridge, or carry on down the Allen.

desc: Low water stunt. Series of very technical rocky slides and falls.
directions: This involves a walk-in from Boot village. Follow a track on the right-hand bank (looking upstream) out of Boot, until you reach Gill Bank Farm. Walk through the yard, cross the bridge and follow the other riverbank up to a waterfall which you can start above or below. Get out in the village of Boot itself.

desc: Small spate trib of the Upper Ure.
Good playrun in high levels, pleasant easy run when lower. Possible alternative putin at Newbridge if you want to shorten the trip.
directions: Takeout in Rhayader, just downstream of the B4518 bridge on river right after Rhayader Falls. Takeout in Builth Wells: follow the one way system round to the carpark on river right just upstream of the A470 bridge.

desc: A popular classic section of the Wye. Watch out for the harder "Hell Hole" rapid just above the chain bridge in Llanstephan.
directions: Putin in Builth Wells: follow the one way system round to the carpark on river right just upstream of the A470 bridge. Takeout in Llyswen just upstream of the bridge on river right.

desc: Beautiful touring run, Whitney makes a good lunch stop.
directions: Putin in Hay-on-Wye: access is a little awkward but there is a footpath on either river left or right just downstream of the bridge. Takeout at the bridge near Bredwardine.

desc: Mellow run, the only interruption is Monington "Falls" which you will probably pass without noticing.
directions: Putin at the minor road bridge near Bredwardine. Takeout in Hereford just downstream of the A49 bridge on river right.

desc: A long touring section that is usually broken into shorter sections: there are plenty of alternative putin/takeouts.
directions: Putin at Hereford just downstream of the A49 bridge on river right. Takeout at the B4260 bridge near Ross-on-Wye (about a km downstream of the A40 bridge).

desc: The classic touring section of the Wye. Highlight is Symonds Yat rapids.
directions: Putin at the B4260 bridge near Ross-on-Wye (about a km downstream of the A40 bridge). Takeout in Monmouth at the rowing club (just off the A40).

desc: OK touring section. Below Tintern the run is tidal so you will want to time your descent to go with the flow.
directions: Putin in Monmouth at the rowing club (just off the A40). Takeout in Chepstow just upstream of the A48 bridge on river right.

desc: Steep and continuous, rarely paddled due to the walkin and high water required.
directions: Takeout in Talybont at the carpark just upstream river right of the A496 bridge. The putin requires a walkin: head upstream along the road opposite the church off the A486 north of Talybont as far as you can, then continue on foot before cutting down to the river.

desc: Well maintained site next to a campsite. A 300m section of grade 2, perfect for introducing beginners to moving water at low levels. Possible to lap multiple times by walking up the river right bank. In high water the mighty Slen-bezi is unleased - surf city.
directions: The turning to Slenningford Water Mill is an obvious left turn when travelling south from West Tanfield.

desc: Popular play spot consisting of a fish ladder and 3m weir. At certain levels a play wave is formed.
Gentle section of the Tees which runs when other sections are too low, or combined with them to make for a longer trip. A couple of surf waves help to maintain the interest.
directions:
Put on where the Balder joins the Tees. Plenty of parking down a small lane in Cotherstone, sign posted "to the river."

Take out either above the big weir before Barnard Castle, using HMYO car park, or at various points in BC or combine with Abbey Rapids for an exciting finish.

desc: A classic introduction to whitewater with Hack Falls and Slenningford Rapids being the highlights. Care should be taken at a number of weirs, in particular Tanfield wier just before Slenningford Rapids
directions: There are several options for the put-in: the most hassle-free is to park at the public car park above Hack Falls and access via the public footpath; Mickley village if you want to avoid Hack Falls; or from Masham for a longer run. Takeout at Slenningford Water Mill, which has a shop, toilets and changing area and may require payment for use of the facilities.

desc: Classic upper section of the Tees. Ledge drop in nature with two larger rapids: "Dog Leg" and "Low Force". Remains fun at low levels, making it a popular run.
directions: Putin at the High Force Hotel, using the footpath just downstream of the footpath to High Force itself. The hotel may try to charge you for access, a contentious issue. To avoid this, there is a car park 600m downstream at the junction with the road up Ettersgill Beck. Takeout either at Wynch Bridge just downstream of Low Force, or continue down to Scooberry Bridge near Newbiggin.

desc: Best when the river is in flood, but remains paddleable at low levels. Flat down to Eggleston Bridge, followed by bouncy grade 3.
directions: Putin at Middleton bridge. Takeout at Cotherstone, head along the track beside the Balder to the river, the turning is easy to miss. It is possible to extend and takeout in Barnard Castle itself.

desc: The highlight of the run is the section preceding Bolton Abbey where the river runs through a pretty gorge which is a popular and well maintained tourist walk. This gorge contains "The Strid", which although not difficult is worth treating with care at low water due to undercuts hidden beneath the surface. Don't let this put you off though as it is easily portageable, and washes out in higher levels.
directions: Put on at Barden Bridge via the public footpath. Get out on river right 100m downstream of Bolton Bridge.

desc: Low grade bimble with a couple of weirs. The weir near Addingham may need portaging.
Mostly mellow water, with a couple of shingly rapids and a playwave at the get out.
directions: Put in at the Slenningford Mill site and take out on the land between the north bridge and the A61 in Ripon where the BCU has purchased some land for this purpose.

desc: Classic Yorkshire pool-drop grade 3: a few feature drops linked by long flat sections. First drop is Conistone Falls, a 1m riverwide ledge. Next is Ghaistrills strid on a LH bend. Finally two weirs lead to Linton Falls, a grade 4 two-tier drop at the takeout.
directions: Putin at Kettlewell, there is a carpark on river left just upstream of the bridge. Takeout on river right just below Linton Falls (in Linton), and scramble up the steep bank to the carpark.

desc: Classic lower section of the Tees. Fun grade 3 trip, an excellent playrun at medium-high levels. Highlights are  Abbey rapids (river narrows into a mini-gorge) and Whorlton Lido (a river-wide reef).
directions: Putin at Barnard Castle: park in the visitors car-park for the young offenders institute and walk down to the river getting on just above the weir. Takeout at Winston bridge (a path leads up from river right just upstream of the bridge). In low levels, the section from Whorlton to Winston may not be worth it, get out at Whorlton using the footpath river left just above the falls. In very low levels, Abbey rapids will still work as a park and play spot, either using the verge on river right above the road bridge, or parking at the Abbey itself.
