desc: Pleasant low grade intro to white water, good for open boats too. Richmond falls can be run at the put-in at grade 4 and there's often a playwave at the Catterick Bridge get-out.
directions:
Put-in by Richmond falls, or the bridge downstream near the station.
Get out at Catterick Bridge after passing under the A1.

desc: Classic waterfall run. Wain Wath Force is the first drop, obvious from the road on the drive up to the putin. The drops get bigger: Rainby Force, then the only real 'rapid' rather than fall, the double drop of Catrake Force, a short easy gorge section then Upper and Lower Kisdon (the last and most serious).
directions: If there is decent levels putin at the Hoggarths road bridge upstream of Keld, and takeout at small bridge on the way to Ivelet (just downstream of Muker). This gives a gentle warm-up and -down either side of the falls. If the water levels are low the falls still go, but the start and end will be barely paddleable. In these conditions it is best to get-on just above Wain Wath falls (visible from the road), and take-out at Lower Kisdon on river right, carrying the km back upstream to Keld via the footpath.

desc: Mostly gentle paddle, with a few bits of continuous grade 2, including the slalom site near the take-out.

Good continuous grade 3 run that ends with 100m of grade 4 just above the confluence with the Tees. The final stretch (including Rokesby falls) is difficult to inspect/portage, so be prepared to read and run.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Rutherford. Takeout after the confluence with the Tees: the first available takeout is river left just above Whorlton Lido (clamber up the steep bank), or continue on the Tees down to Winston Bridge as it will be at a fun level if the Greta is running.

desc: An extra few kms to add to the start of the Greta at a slightly easier grade to the rest. The weir above Rutherford Bridge can be dodgy in high water.
directions:
Put-in from the footpath at Gilmonby Bridge, down the road from Bowes (easier to park in Bowes and walk down the hill). Walking a few hundred metres upstream will allow you to run Mill Force (3+) as a warm up.
You can take out at Rutherford Bridge, but would be better to continue on down the next section.

section: Cupola Bridge to South Tyne Confluence
desc: A fun trib of the South Tyne, containing boulder garden rapids and a 6ft sloping weir (Hagg Fall).
directions: Put in at Cupola Bridge. Take out either at Plankey Mill or continue down the South Tyne to Haydon Bridge.

desc: Fun grade 3 run after the 6m grade 4 waterfall at the start. If running all the way to Stanhope, beware of the sticky weir above the bridge.
directions: Highest put-in is at the bridge in Cowshill (technically on Killhope Burn), if you drive up from Wearhead you will see the waterfall from the road that you want to put-in above. If you don't want to run the waterfall, pr levels are low, put-in at Wearhead. Various take-outs possible, either at the bridges in Daddry Shield or Eastgate or above the ford in Stanhope.

desc: A trib of the Swale, which runs in high water. Starts off as fast continuous grade 3 from Whaw in decent water, with few eddies. Mellows a bit in the middle, and gets shallow where the river splits into various channels. Steeps up a bit again as you approach Reeth. There's one sheep fence to be aware of and trees are always going to be an issue, particuarly towards the end.
directions:
If the water is high put in at the road bridge in Whaw where there's space for a couple of cars, otherwise use the road bridge above Langthwaite. In very high water it may be possible to put-in even higher up for added fast grade 3.
Take out either in Reeth or in Grinton after the Swale confluence, or continue down the Swale.

desc: Spate beck formed from the confluence of Euden and Spurlswood Becks in Hamsterley forest. A few gorgy sections of grade 3. Obviously trees can be an issue!
directions: Put-in points at various places within Hamsterley forest. The highest available being the confluence of Euden and Spurlswood at Grove Park. Follow the Forest Drive through Hamsterley, use one of the car parks and put-on as high up as you feel like. Multiple get-outs from the bridge in Bedburn down to the Wear itself where it passes under the A68.

desc: A variety of excellent continuous gorges and drops, but some mandatory portages in the form of High Force and Aira Force, best to thoroughly inspect first.
directions: Either put-in in Dockray, or walk in higher up via the public footpath. Get out either from Ullswater itself or under the A592 road bridge.

desc: Playspot near Leeds. Beautiful glassy wave if you catch it at the right level.
directions: Playspot to the SE of Leeds, just downstream of Woodlesford rail station. From Aberford Rd (A642) head down Fleet Lane to the oil storage depot (just after the bridge over the canal). This is on an island formed by the canal and the river. Park up and walk downstream 200m to a bridge over the river to see if the wave is in condition.

desc: An adventure in Kielder Forest.
directions: Turn off the road running alongside Keilder Water itself onto a track up towards Buck Fell.

desc: Excellent fast and steep run, the walkin is rewarded.
directions: Turn off the A55 at Abergwyngregyn and follow signs for Aber Falls. At the carpark head left up a small steep road to another small carpark. This is the takeout: the putin is a strenuous but rewarding walkin continuing up along the track out from the carpark.

desc: Spate stream, often with plenty of trees in.
directions: Take the B4577 Aberarth to Pennant road inland to the getin at a little bridge. The takeout is in Aberarth town itself below the falls.

desc: Fun spate run, can be used as a warm-up for the Nantcol.
directions: Takeout at Llanbedr on the A496. To get to the putin drive upstream from Llanbedr keeping to river-right. Access to the river is possible from the footpath bridge leading to Cwn Yr Afon.

section: Top of Snake Pass to Alport Confluence
desc: Steep continuous with tiny eddies and plenty of trees and fences. The rapids are not super hard but it's easy to mess it up or underestimate this run, especially when high.

In theory an excellent spate beck with continuous boulder rapids and a few big falls for good measure. Unfortunately, the amount of wood and fences spoils it somewhat meaning a lot of portages are currently required.
directions: Take the road to Tan Hill from Brough via Barras. Park just after the forest where a track leads down into the woods by a small stone bridge. Follow the track a short way but before entering the wood head off down the hill following the wall across some boggy ground to join the river. Get out on the left bank just below Oxenthwaite Bridge.

desc: From the viaduct the river starts at grade 2, building to beautiful continuous grade three through pine-forest. The main event of the trip (grade 4) comes up suddenly and eddies are limited. Best option is scout/portage left.
directions: Ample parking is available at the obvious put-in; the huge (and picturesque) viaduct at the end of the road. Follow the road south taking two left turns (the second being a tight switchback to reach the takeout bridge.

desc:
A tidal playboating spot at a line of rocks that jut out into Ramsey Sound between Ramsey Island and the mainland. It is best to go out about 3hrs before high water and warm-up on the increasing flow of the tide.

Two main spots exist. A hole, closer to the island, and the "main wave" further out. Have a look for the queues of boaters if you're unsure!
directions: Paddle southwards from St Justinians, starting at the steps by the Lifeboat Station, up the giant eddy formed by the Pen Dal-Aderyn headland. Once you can't get any further, start the ferry across Ramsey Sound to The Bitches. Play 'till your hearts content, then make the mother of all ferry's back to the lifeboat station. Note that Horse Rock, right in the middle of this ferry can produce dangerous currents. Either cut above  it, or drop below. If in doubt seek local advice.

section: Barkisland Paper Mills to Calder Confluence
desc: Industrial adventure with trees and sluices to contend with...
A small trib of the Etherow filled with boulder gardens and slides
directions: Walk-in up the path from the Etherow and put on as high as you like.

desc: Starting off gently for the first 4km, this spate beck gathers pace to become continuous grade 3/4 and contains one harder fall. Look out for sheep fences throughout the upper section and the weir under the motorway at the end!
directions: The shuttle for this is a bit of a monster - the price you pay for getting to paddle a river in a beautiful valley with no roads! For the put-in, it is possible to park on the A6 and walk down to the river, alternatively take the farm track parallel to the A6, the junction of which is about 1km south of the A6 bridge over the river. There is plenty of parking here.

desc: A short, steep mountain-surfing stunt if you've done everything else in upper Wharfedale and it's still raining. Point downstream and hold on - that's about it. Be sure to find the eddy below the long slide and take out.... there's a fence just below.
directions: From Buckden village, carry up the beck a couple of hundred yards to below the waterfall, putting on at the (too shallow) plungepool.

section: Forest Walk bridge to Talybont-on-Usk Reservoir
desc: Small spate stream, probably only worth doing if you're passing. The upper section is rumoured to be a good gd5 run.
directions: Head onto the small the C road linking Talybont-on-Usk to Pontsticill.

desc: A 300m section of the Calder which has been modified to provide a good introduction to white water, play boating or slalom practice. Maintained by Halifax Canoe Club - contact them for further details.
directions:
Halifax CC are located in Greenups Mill in the centre of Sowerby Bridge, near Halifax. From the bridge over the river you can see the put-in and the course.

Parking within the mill complex is for residents only, there is a big car park at the rear of B&M supermaket  next to the canal. You can drop your boat at the club, but to avoid any problems with residents move your car as soon as you have unloaded.

desc: Picturesque grade 2. One broken weir to look out for. Alternative start from Millhouse is possible if the levels are high and you're worried about trees.
directions: Small car park on river left just below Sebergham bridge.

desc: Meandering grade 1 with bits of 2, one large weir near the end which is a prudent portage (left) at high levels, though good fun to run when the stopper at the bottom doesn't look too mean.
directions: Carpark just below the bridge on river left at Sebergham. From here drive west to the B5299 and turn right to Dalston. There is a footbridge and small car park on river left near the centre of town.

desc: Wide meandering section with two weirs to be aware of. The first small weir is just after a railway bridge and washes out in high water but can be very grabby at certain levels. The second is a big drop onto a ledge. A definite portage. The route round both is on river right. You can take out here, or continue through Carlisle itself.
directions: A small carpark, accessed from the middle of Dalston provides a convenient put-in. The takeout is just before the confluence with the Eden with a large car park behind the castle.

section: Afon Wen confluence to upper Gerlan bridge
desc: Requires a 2-3km walkin. First km is easier gd3, then run builds to continuous gd4. At the takeout bridge just before the confluence with the Llafar is a gd5 drop. It is possible to continue downriver from here but it can be a little sketchy.
directions: Find the small road bridge above Gerlan in Bethesda, this is the takeout. By back-tracking downhill and then taking the first right, follow a small road to the start of the walkin (follow the footpath upstream!).

desc: Pleasant spate run, usually with a few wires and trees to dodge. About halfway down is a small friendly brick weir.
directions: Takeout along a small road on river left that heads downstream from the A44 road bridge near Crossgates. To reach the putin head upstream via the A483 then onto small roads towards Abby-cwm-hir to reach a small road bridge over the river.

desc: A small trib of the Glen, the main interest is several falls in Hethpool gorge - the hardest of which is the constricted Hethpool Linn.
Fast flowing to begin with, before slowing down to touring pace as the river plateaus in the flood plains.
directions: Put in off the road bridge in Low Alnwinton and get out at the bridge in Rothbury. Thropton Bridge may be used as a put-in for a shorter trip.

desc: A spate run with a few harder falls and rapids near the source.
directions: Follow the road from Alnwinton up into the Cheviots. The road follows the river and water levels will dictate how far up you drive before putting on, with Blindburn being the highest point. Get out at the bridge in Low Alnwinton.

desc: Excellent touring run, with a funky gorge section. Takeout just after the confluence with the Tywi.
directions: Putin at the bridge upstream of the A482 road bridge near Pumpsaint. Takeout at the B4310 road bridge just off the A40 near Nantgaredig.

desc: Described by the few who have run it as Yorkshire's best beck. Short and very steep, plenty of falls packed in, some with shallow landings. Needs lots of water, so rarely run.
directions: Either put-in above the big fall in Cray village, or in very high water continue up the road to where the Gill crosses the road again and put on below here.

desc: Good waterfall run when its up. The first 500m is a rocky grade 2/3, before you reach a series of drops with deep plunge pools. The hardest is probably the last, and you can inspect from the takeout by walking up river right.
directions: From the A4085 turn off at Garreg Llanfrothen and head up to the putin in the village of Croesor. Takeout by the cliffs  of Carreg Hyll Drem on the A4085.

section: Hazel Bank to Borrow Beck confluence
desc: A series of bedrock rapids and drops, with two of note. One is a rocky 5 foot drop immediately followed by a narrow slot and a boiling hole. The second is a chossy slide dropping with a couple of overhanging trees to keep things jazzy.
directions: Best run as an addition to Borrow Beck, the put-in can be found by taking a right hand turn onto a farm track about 1km south of the A6 bridge over Borrow Beck. Follow this parallel to the A6, over Borrow Beck, continuing until you can see the flat upper reaches of Crookdale Beck. Park in the area where there is no wall to cross and walk 100m to the put-in.

desc: Slightly bonkers continuous run down a Snowdon runoff ditch. Steep and continuous, and lots of fun apart from the walkin.
directions: Park at a small layby about halfway between Llyn Dinas and Beddgelert from where a major footpath heads up towards Snowdon. Walk the boats in up this path as it climbs to meet the river (about 2km).

section: Garth Gell bridge to Pen y Bryn
desc: The first 600m is an easy warmup before you drop into a steep boulder garden. A short break follows before entering the lower gorge with a set of narrow drops and sticky holes that can be sketchy in higher water.
directions: Takeout at the A496 road bridge at Pen-y-bryn. To reach the putin head upstream to the next road bridge over the river.

desc: A tough run. The top 3km is ditch-bashing, but contains some good drops. As you reach the first of the Nantcol gorges, the drops get more difficult, followed by easier second gorge. Takeout at the confluence with the Artro.
directions: Takeout at the road bridge just after the confluence with the Artro near Pentre Gwynfryn. Head upstream and putin at the second road bridge over the river.

section: Upper Cynfal Gorge to Cwm Farm
desc: This is a series of drops, slots and slides ranging between 10ft-70ft. Take climbing gear for the Rhaeadr Y Cwm portage. You're in for an adventure!

section: Lower Section to Pont Tal y Bont
desc: First up is a constriction finishing into a boxed in weir. Can scout right/portage right if its low enough. 50m later is a clean 20ft drop which is hard to scout, best taken middle or left. Second 20fter take on river right as there is a tree on river left. Still a clean line. The final 500m is grade 2/3 through a jungle of trees. Has been done without portages - but good luck!
directions: Walk up from the bottom on river left. There should be a trail leading down into the gorge at the second style/gate. Get on after the tree choke.

desc:
Lots of smooth slides and a few drops in open moorland.

Hop over the first dam onto the second reservoir, but be very cautious of the sink hole at the far left close to the dam!
directions:
Walk-in via the Pennine Way from the A635.

Take out near the car park on river left of Digley Reservoir.

desc: An excellent touring paddle. Takeout just above Horseshoe Falls on river left.
directions: Putin at the small bridge in Corwen just downstream of the main A5 road bridge. To reach the takeout head towards Llangollen and just before you reach it cross the river at Berwyn along the B5103 and use the carpark on river left.

desc: Another touring section as the Dee winds its way to the sea.
directions: Putin in Bangor-is-y-Coed at the narrow bridge just downstream of the main A525 road bridge. Takeout at the narrow road bridge in the village of Farndon (just downstream of where the A534 crosses the river).

desc: The first few kms act as a warm up to Ibbeth Peril Falls - a 3m slide into a large plunge pool. To the right of the fall is an undercut cliff containing Ibbeth Peril Cave - a pothole which you won't want to be anywhere near! Below this are three more hard falls, all of which have now been paddled, but a portage of the middle one may be advisable. The river then eases off to grade 3, before becoming flat for the last few kms down to Dent.

Fast flowing grade 1 and 2 leads to a bridge, which may require ducking under. A small bedrock fall follows shortly, and leads into boulder rapids in the trees. From here the amount of bedrock picks up, and shallow slides as well as boulder rapids make up the run. Further downstream the river enters a wooded area, and the hardest rapid on the run in a mini gorge. Inspection sensible, due to trees and undercuts. After this, the river continues on downstream through a series of mini bedrock gorges, with nice class 3 rapids, until the take out. Alternatively, carry on into the Dee.
directions:
Park at the waterfall where Deepdale lane crosses Gastack Beck - head to the river from here. The waterfall at the layby at gastack beck may be runnable if it's big water - somewhere between 15 - 20ft.

Take Out at Dyke Hall Lane or carry on into the Dee.

desc: Watch out for the weirs, some have nasty tow-back.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Oughtibridge, and takeout in Hillfoot near Sheffield's dry ski slope.

desc: Grade 1/2 with weirs

section: Abbey Dore to Great Corras bends
desc: An interesting narrow but easy paddle. Keep an eye out for Cupid's Hill weir, about a km downstream of the Monnow confluence.
directions: To reach the putin turn off the B4347 at Abbey Dore and get on at the Court Gardens bridge. Takeout after the confluence with the Monnow at a small footbridge just before the great Corras bends: this can be reached by heading down river left along small roads from the B4347 bridge at Kentchurch.

desc: Fun bouncy run. The harder drop is about halfway down as the banks close in. Watch out for fences.
directions: Takeout at the small bridge in Heolyrhedyn (just north of Ystradfellte) at the confluence with the Llia. To reach the putin head south up a steep hill and take a small road on the left upstream. Head up here for a few km and then park and walk down to the river.

desc: A lazy summer afternoon paddle.
directions: Takeout at the A483 roadbridge just east of Llandeilo and Rhosmaen. To reach the putin head north along the B4302 from Llandeilo and take  the first of two very close right turns after Taliaris.

desc: Unremarkable grade 3 run. The hardest rapid is after an old railway bridge: a long steep grade 4. Takeout on river left before reaching Aberdulais Falls which would be a definite portage.
directions: Takeout near the A4109 bridge in Aberdulais (just off the main A465). From the bridge head a little way upstream up river left through a housing estate to find somewhere where you can access the river. To reach the putin head upstream along the A4109 and take a small turnoff to a bridge just north of Crynant.

desc: An easy spate trib of the Irfon. A few fences to avoid, and an obvious weir halfway down.
directions: Takeout at the A483 road bridge near Garth. To reach the putin head back to Beulah and then north along the B4358, putting in where it crosses the river.

desc: Fast and easy until a sequence of falls: Rhaedr y Pwll Du, or "The Falls of the Black Pool". After this the water eases, but keep an eye out for wires across the river.
directions: Takeout at Esgairgeiliog bridge just off the A487 about a km south of Corris. To reach the putin head towards Aberllefenni from Corris along small roads. Stay right after passing through the village and you'll end up at a bridge over the river.

desc: Unremarkable grade 3 run. There is a weir almost immediately after the putin, and watch out for a portage round a fall immediately below a rock island (riber right is easiest).
directions: Putin at a small bridge just off the A487 about a km south of Corris. Takeout at the B4404 bridge at Ffiddgate.

section: Henllan bridge to Garth campsite bridge
desc: An excellent little run with plenty of good drops. The harder drop is similar to Brown's Falls on the Llugwy, on a LH bend about 400m downstream of Forge.
directions: To reach the takeout head east from Machynlleth along the A489, taking a left to head downstream immediately after crossing the river. Keep going downstream as far as is practical. To reach the putin head back to Machynlleth and head upstream to cross the river at Forge. From here keep going up river right for about 5km to the second small bridge over the river.

section: Fron Oleu Bridge to Bont Fechan
desc: A fun little run, with a few tree/fence obstacles.
directions: Takeout at the small bridge just off the A497 where it crosses the river east of Llanystumdwy. Putin at a bridge near Ynys, which can be reached from a small road of the B4411 which links the A497 and the A487.

desc: A relaxed run, with a kick in the tail as there are a series of 3 harder drops just above the takeout.
directions: Turn off the A470 towards Llanymawddwy at Dinas Mawddwy. The takeout is in the village itself. To reach the putin continue heading upstream to a bridge in Llanymawddwy.

desc: A gentle run, the hardest rapid is just after the confluence with the Dugoed.
directions: Putin in Dinas Mawddwy. To reach the takeout head south along the A470 and get out at the bridge in Aberangell.

desc: An easy and beautiful touring section. If you want a shorter trip it is possible to get on/off at the B4404 bridge about halfway down.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Aberangell. Takeout at the A487 bridge just north of Machynlleth.

section: Abergynolwyn to the old Bryncrug road bridge
desc: A beautiful touring run with no nasties.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Abergynolwyn just off the B4405. Takeout at the disused bridge just next the main A493 road bridge east of Bryncrug.

desc: A very scenic float trip with a couple of grade 2 rapids to keep things interesting, the first of which is immediately after the put-in.
directions: The river is a short walk southwards from a small road just off the westbound A66. Takeout just after the bridge in Langwathby.

desc: A fairly continuous spate beck, with one 3m fall.
directions: In spate conditions the river is runnable from Sinderhope Ford. Get out either at Thornley Gate Bridge just outside of Allendale Town, or continue to Cupola Bridge on the Allen.

desc: Adventurous day out: plenty of steep slides and technical drops. Watch out for the 6m waterfall (portage river right).
directions: Takeout next to Okehampton College. To reach the putin drive up through Belstone to the end of the road and then walk the final 2km in to Cullever Steps (along the Tarka Trail).

desc: Easy shingle rapids on a meandering river bed. One small weir near the start.

section: Great Musgrave to Appleby in Westmorland

desc: Eden Lacey falls are about 2/3rds of the way down this section - look out for a viaduct crossing the river. Inspect from river left if you need to.
directions: Put-in river left, just downstream of the bridge in Langwathby. A large car-park just above the bridge near Lazonby provides a convenient takeout.

desc: Easy scenic run, ideal for beginners.
directions: Put-in river right just below the bridge in Armathwaite - if you're feeling adventurous you can put in ~0.5km upstream on river left to take on the mighty Armathwaite weir. Takeout on river left just downstream of Wetheral, upstream of the weir.

desc: The playspot works well at high and low levels. Somewhere between this it closes in and forms a nasty hole. Make your own mind up when you get there.
directions: A convenient layby just downstream on river left provides good access to the spot.

desc: An easily accessible spot for practicing and introducing beginners to moving water without the need for a shuttle.
directions: Park in the Sands Leisure Centre car-park. Head to the river and walk ~100m upstream to the rapid.

desc: Good alternative start to the river Wye.
directions: Putin just below Cabin Coch dam at a bridge in Elan village. Either takeout at junction pool at the confluence with the Wye (the small road on river right has good access) or continue down the Wye.

desc: A more remote and harder version of the classic Etive. A long walk-in rewards you with a series of pool-drop waterfalls of varying difficulty.
directions: Park up in Brotherilkeld, take the river left path and keep walking! Either put in at the Pack Horse bridge near the Lingcove Beck confluence, or if you want to do the Eskdale Waterfalls, carry on 1/2km upstream.

desc: An expedition into the Yorkshire Moors in heavy rain may result in finding this river up. It consists of three gorges running at grade 3 (possibly 4 in high levels) connected by flat water.
directions: It is possible to put in at Castleton, but this only adds another 10km of arduous flat water. The normal put-in is therefore a mile or two above Lealholm, under a railway bridge and along a footpath across a field. Parking here is difficult, we dropped the boats and parked in a layby a few hundred metres further up the road on the left. Get out river right at Egton Bridge.

desc: Mostly a grade 2 bimble with a couple of weirs and the option to paddle out to sea at the end!
directions: Put in at Egton Bridge and take out at Whitby Harbour.

section: Salter's Brook Bridge to Woodhead Reservoir
desc: Continuous steep spate stream.
directions:
There is easy access from the A628 at the road bridge at Salters Brook. Park in a layby just before the bridge. 
Take out above a big weir a little way above Woodhead reservoir. There is a small road leading down to a good parking spot here just off the A628.

desc: A good introduction to whitewater for beginners or as a touring run: lots of small natural rapids and a few weirs. Bolham weir at the takeout is nasty: portage around on river right and then paddle across the river downstream of the weir to takeout by the road on river left.
directions: Putin at Bridgetown, or you could shorten the trip by putting in at Exebridge. Takeout at Bolham weir, about 2km north of Tiverton along the A386.

desc: A pleasant touring or beginners run, flat apart from weirs and other man-made rapids.
directions: Putin at Shawford bridge, the A36 bridge just south of Woolverton. Parking is tricky here. Takeout at Iford bridge (the minor road bridge east of Westwood), or continue for an extra 2km to takeout at a bridge in Freshford.

desc: Rumour has it that Aysgill Force has been run, but only in high water by the very brave. The rest of the beck contains many small rapids and shelf drops, particuarly from above the village of Gayle and into Hawes itself, some of which have shallow landings.
directions:
Take the footpath from the Beggarmans road in Sleddale to Aysgill Force and put on below this.

Take out either in Hawes where parking is available (although you may have to fight the tourists), or continue onto the Ure and take out at Hayland Bridge.

section: Dorwen ar Giedd to Tawe confluence
desc: Good gorge section, combined with the Nant Cyw makes a good day.
directions: Takeout at the A4067 bridge in Cwmgiedd. Head upstream along small roads on river left and get on from a layby near the Nant Cyw confluence.

desc: A pleasant touring run.
directions: The putin in a bit tricky. You need to get on somewhere downstream of the A498/A4085 Pont Aberglaslyn junction. There are a few laybys downstream with access to the river. Takeout river left near Porthmadog where the A487 runs alongside the river.

desc: A pushy low volume lakeland beck with plenty of falls and slides near the top and a slightly more moderate section leading into the Tarn.
directions: A long walk in up the path on river right is required. Put in below the unrunnable falls at the mine workings.

desc: Small spate stream which joins Oughtershaw Beck to form the Wharfe. Narrow and quite continuos - look out for fences and a surprise small fall on a bend. Worth doing as a warm up for the Upper Wharfe in high water.
directions: Drive past the farmyard at the get-in for the Upper Wharfe in Beckmonds. You'll need to open a couple of gates on the road. When you see a forestry track on the right, park here and walk down to the river on the left. It may be paddleable higher up in spate, but the road is private above this point making access tricky.

section: Off the footpath to Swale Confluence
desc: If Swaledale is flooded this will go as a constant flume ride from however high up you want to walk.
directions:
Park in Gunnerside and walk up as high as you fancy/looks runnable.
Either take out in the village or continue down the Swale.

desc: A beautiful flat river, good for beginners or touring.
directions: Putin at the small bridge just downstream of the Llangyndeyrn (B4306) road bridge. Takeout at Llanadog bridge, the first bridge upstream of the main A484 bridge.

desc: Small fast spate beck with one large waterfall (Goit Stock).

This run starts on Harthope Burn and turns into Wooler water after 4km. Starting off small, there's a small gorge after the confluence, the odd small fall and weirs towards the end. Higher up the valley a walk in will reveal Harthope Linn - a 20ft waterfall which may not yet have seen a descent.

section: Tyn y Cwm to Garth Goch
desc: Trees and fences make this run more painful than enjoyable, although there are a couple of nice drops.
directions: Takeout at the B4403 bridge just east of Bala. To reach the putin head up minor roads to Rhos-y-gwaliau, cross to river left and head upstream for another 2km to a large lay-by next to the river.

desc: Tight, steep and technical with numerous crunchy waterfalls. It is worth inspecting the whole run from the footpath on river right before you get on.
directions: Putin at Hillsford Bridge near the junction between the A39 and the B3223, where you can climb down to the river. The Hoaroak ends at the confluence with the East Lyn where it is possible to get out although most will want to continue down the East Lyn to Lynmouth.

desc: Touring run with the occasional weir.
directions: Putin at the B6478 bridge at Slaidburn. Takeout at High Hodder Bridge, which is the road bridge directly east of Clitheroe.

desc: The Holme is rarely paddled  probably due to the scarcity of a decent amount of water. However, if deep enough, it offers a picturesque paddle with a frequent variety of features. Its course is heavily wooded for the most part and you will be unaware that in some sections you are passing through a small town. The occasional bankside mill and the number of weirs give a clue to the industrial past of the area. At lower levels, some parts can be a little scrapey but the most notable and enjoyable features are the rapids which occur in several short sections. The best of these is at Smithy Place in Brockholes just after the road bridge which links the A616 and A6024. There are another potentially quite gnarly set at the take out directly below the second vertical weir described above.
directions:
Sands playing fields are on the outskirts of Holmfirth next to Holmfirth Swimming Baths on the A6024. There is a large free car park right next to the river here. However, this may be busy on winter Sunday mornings due to the adjacent football pitches. The adventurous can put in above the footbridge and tackle the almost immediate 1.7m vertical drop. For the more sedate, (and those of us who have noticed shopping trolleys in the weir before now, ) it is very easy to cross the footbridge, walk a few metres downstream and put in in the adjacent woodland. Look out for the Herons which often feed here.
The take-out is at the confluence with Mag Brook just before Steps Industrial Park to the north of Honley. Take the A6024 from Holmfirth. About half-a-mile after this joins the A616, there is a road to the left which is signposted Magdale. On-street parking is available here before the bridge. The take-out is reached via the public footpath which runs along the front of the houses on the Western bank. Get out on the left bank at the junction of the two rivers.

desc: Unremarkable gd3 run, which requires decent water.
directions: Takeout in Brecon, parking at the carpark at the confluence with the Usk. Head upstream along the B4520 and putin at the bridge in Llandefaelog. If you wish to make the run longer, it is also possible to get on upstream at the bridge in Lower Chapel.

desc: A brilliant canyoning gorge, in places 15m deep and 2m wide, not the place for a kayak... or is it? Highly recommended on an inner tube when water is up a bit, though you will need it partially inflated for some of the tighter slides and flumes. Not recommended in high water. The only escape from the gorge is halfway down through the hidden cave... if you can find it. No ropes required.
directions: Head for Lofthouse in Upper Nidderdale. The village of Stean is nearby, with a couple of tourist car parks.

desc: Pleasant touring paddle. The harder 2+ rapid is near the end as you enter Builth Wells. Takeout shortly after joining the Wye.
directions: Putin at the B4519 bridge (just off the A483) near Garth, or if you want to make the run 4km longer use the bridge in Llangammarch Wells. Takeout from the Wye in the carpark next to the river in Builth Wells.

desc: A pretty and remote feeling run, with two rapids of note and a monster of a drop at the takeout. Inspection/portage up the steep bank on river right.
directions: Drive past the put-in for the Crammel Linn section, and continue on up to Butterburn. The takeout above Crammel Linn requires a walk downstream and away from the river, following the footpath to your waiting car.

desc: Meandering grade 2 with a couple of harder rapids to keep the interest.
directions: Put in river left a hundred metres or so upstream of the bridge in Gilsland. Parking is limited so be careful. The best takeout is river right just upstream of the bridge near Holmehead. The best parking however is a bit of a trek back upstream on river left.

desc: One weir in Kendal to be aware of in high flows, the remainder is a fun float through Kendal and a nice way to make a full day out of a trip down the Sprint, Mint or upper Kent by linking it with the lower Kent.
directions: Downstream of the bridge (river right) in Burneside is a small park and area for parking; an ideal put-in spot. Traverse Kendal, and just as you leave the residential area heading south on the A6, a small road turns off from a lay-by on the left. Drive right down to the end and there's a fairly sizeable parking area next to the river.

desc: Low volume, steep countinuous grade 4 rapids and slides, with some big falls reaching grade 5. One or two may need portaging.
directions: Park at Alance bridge at the top of Yarrow reservoir and walk up the track and paths on river right from there.

desc: An excellent spate beck with a high-end grade four gorge containing several small falls.
directions: Park at the top of the track for Smithy House Farm and walk down from here. When you reach the river you may want to walk back upstream to the resurgence. Get out at Cowan Bridge on the left after the railway bridge.

desc: Narrow stream running through agricultural land. Lots of sheep fences to sneak and/or portage, but good fun if you like exploring.
directions: Coming from the A6, cross the bridge and take the bridleway on the left when the road turns right. Put in just downstream of the railway bridge.

desc: Possibly not worth driving a long way for, but best done if you're in the area having done one of the other rivers in the area. The section consists of a series of drops which get increasingly more difficult as the levels go up.
directions: Park and put-in just below Penton Bridge, get out at the bottom and walk back up for another lap!

desc: Starts with an optional 18m fall. The rest is continuous 3/4 including a tight gorge with a double drop.
directions: Put in above (or below) Linhope Spout, We drove into Linhope crossed over the burn and parked at the end of the road NT 964 162. There are a couple of signs saying local access only, but upon being polite to the residents there was no problem parking here! Alternatively, you could park just before Linhope NT 976 162 and walk along the public footpath to Linhope and then follow the stone track up to the spout. Upon reaching the corner of the plantation, a fingerpost guides you off the stone track and onto a clear grassy track. Follow this up a slope alongside the plantation and through a gate. Follow the path as it zig-zags down the hill to the Linhope Burn and Linhope Spout waterfall NT 956171 . Suggested take out would be on the River Breamish at the last road bridge before Linhope NT 997 166. We got off before the confluence with the Breamish on the estate track.

section: Black Sail YHA to Ennerdale Water
desc: Spate stream in the Ennerdale forests. Starts with continuous 3/4 with three harder rapids before dropping a grade for the final few km to the lake.
directions: Very difficult to get to as cars aren't meant to go up the forestry track, so a long walk from Bowness Knott, or over Scarth Gap for a shorter, but steeper alternative.

section: Forestry parking place to Afon Mellte
desc: Fast and fun, but watch out for trees and fences. About halfway down on a LH bend is a 6m waterfall with a shallow landing.
directions: Takeout at the road bridge at the confluence with the Dringarth river (just north of Ystradfellte). To reach the putin head north up a steep hill, then take a small turnoff down to the river just after entering the woods.

desc: Easy water leads down to the first grade 5 as the river gorges up slightly into a RH bend. The next major challenge is a 300m cateract, its difficulty depending a lot on the level. Scout along the small path on river left.
directions: Takeout at a small foot bridge about 0.5km upstream of the A494 bridge: access from the small road on river left, the footbridge is just upstream of the caravan park. To reach the putin keep heading upstream along the road on river left. Go through the village of Dothendre and then up a steep bit of the road until the huge Lliw Falls become visible. Get on from a layby just upstream of the farm buildings, and make sure you get on below a cateract leading out from the falls.

desc: Spate ditch, gets harder from start to finish with the final ("Brown's") falls the highlight.
directions: Takeout behind Brown's climbing shop at the junction between the A4086 and the A5 at Capel Curig. Find a convenient putin by heading north along the A5 from the takeout, you can see the river from the road.

desc: Fun park-n-huck in low conditions. The final drop is not normally run (portage river right), and depending on the levels can be a bit sketchy to eddy out before!
directions: Heading south towards Betws-y-Coed from Capel Curig park at the large layby near the first road bridge across the river (a small single-track turn-off from the A5) after passing the Cobdens Fall Hotel.

desc: Swallows Falls can be paddled as a park-n-slide in low conditions, at higher levels you would normally getin underneath the main falls. These falls are usually sneaked down the river right channel, although it has been main-lined down the centre. A kilomtre or so of easier water follows until you reach another 500m of tough drops culminating at Miner's bridge, a footbridge across the river. Either getout here or continue down a short stretch of easier water to Betws-y-Coed. If you do continue downstream, there is another tough drop behind the chip-shop in the middle of town.
directions: Putin at Swallow Falls on the A5 just north of Betws-y-Coed: there is a large layby opposite the Swallow Falls Hotel. Takeout at Miner's Bridge just at the outskirts of Betws-y-Coed or continue down into the town.

section: Pont Rhyd y Cyff to Bridgend
desc: A pleasant touring river.
directions: Putin at the bridge on the minor road off the A4063 that leads to Bettws. Takeout at the bridge near Glanrhyd Hospital in Bridgend, just south of the M4.

desc: Fun but random river: shortly after putting on, you are forced to weave your way through "the jungle". It's mostly flat until reaching a tunnel, and some good rapids follow in the 2nd half. Takeout at the A499 road bridge, or it's possible to continue into the sea and end the trip with a brief surf.
directions: Putin at the exit of Llyn Nantlle, where the B4418 Rhyd Ddu to Penygroes road crosses the river. If you want to avoid the "jungle" putin at the next bridge down. Takeout at the A499 bridge, or paddle all the way to the sea and takeout from the beach.

desc: Ridiculous steep shallow giggle of a ditch which acts as an amusing start to the classic Lune section. A few small falls and slides, beware the piton rock on one of the drops in the middle and the temptation to take the left line on the final slide!
directions: As you are walking down to the Lune from Beck Foot, this is the river that follows the road on your right. Put on where it's right next to the road and still looks flat.

desc: A pleasant touring run with a lot of weirs and fences to negotiate.
directions: Putin at the B4357 road bridge just south of Whitton (the next bridge downstream of the A488 Monaughty bridge). Takeout just before the confluence with the Wye at a small road bridge just off the B4362 near Combe.

desc: A short Tees trib which runs when the reservoir is releasing, usually in high water levels. Trees are always going to be an issue here! The river splits a few hundred metres before the Tees, with the right channel taking more water.
directions: Put-in below the dam, next to the Caravan site. If you're running this ditch you'll probably combine it with a section of the Tees, getting out at Eggleston Bridge (difficult access) or Cotherstone.

desc: Scrappy but fun. Be careful at the takeout, egress well above the A386 bridge on river right: otherwise you get drawn into the tunnel under the road, and downstream is the unpaddleable Lydford gorge.
directions: Takeout at the A386 bridge north of Tavistock. To reach the putin take the track off the A386 between the Dartmoor Inn and the petrol station up to the river.

desc: A few small rapids early in in the first half, ease off for the second section. It is possible to shorten the trip by starting/stopping at some of the bridges en route.
Good touring or beginner's trip: a mellow introduction to moving water.
directions: Putin at Kerney Bridge, just west of Golberdon. Takeout at Notter Bridge: just upstream of the A38 bridge west of Saltash.

section: Maulds Meaburn to Cliburn Mill Bridge
desc: A couple of small weirs add interest to this grade 2 run.
directions: Both put-in and take out on river right. From the put-in, the road via King's Meaburn is the fastest way to the take-out.

desc: A fun meandering paddle, good for beginners. Be careful to make the takeout.
directions: Putin from a small footpath just off the B4406 about a km upstream of Penmachno. Takeout just ABOVE the bridge at Penmachno Woollen Mill just before the confluence with the Conwy. This final section to the confluence is pot-holed grade 5, best avoided.

desc: Watch out for the weir just below the confluence. Public Toilet Falls follows, and then a series of bouldery bouncy rapids before the run mellows towards the takeout as the road comes close on river left.
directions: Putin at the small bridge just off he A470 at the confluence with the Eden. Head down the small road on river left (the opposite side to the A470) and choose a convenient takeout at one of the points where the road is close to the river.

desc: The old mine workings is where the fun bit starts and isn't a bad walk down an obvious track - park by the stile at the top of the hill on the little road up from Westgate.The highlight of the run is a tunnel to boof to tunnel combo in the middle of the old mine workings, and carries on down into the wooded gorge below. This is very pleasant grade 3 with regular small ledge drops to keep up the interest. A bit tree-ey at the moment though, but the interest will continue all the way down to Westgate.
Pleasant touring paddle, a few weirs but nothing nasty.
directions: To reach the putin turn off the A465 at Pandy and head north to a bridge just before Longtown. Takeout at a small footbridge just before the great Corras bends: this can be reached by heading down river left along small roads from the B4347 bridge at Kentchurch.

desc: Continuous grade 2 leads to the first short tunnel. A section of tree/fence/bridge dodging follows before a 70m tunnel (be careful of possible debris!). As the river nears Glyncoch you reach an excellent grade 4 gorge.
directions: Putin at the bridge on the small road between Ynysybwl and Perthcelyn (heading upstream along river right). Takeout in Glyncoch just before the confluence with the Taff, at the bridge just downstream of the railway (on Abercynon Road).

desc: Appearance of a ditch hides a couple of good gorge sections.
directions: From the bridge at the bottom of the Abergalsyn Gorge (the junction of the A498 and A4085 near Beddgelert) head along the A4085 towards Dolgellau. Almost immediately take a road on the left that follows Nantmor upstream. Keep going until the river is too thin to paddle, and get on. Various takeouts are possible, scout one out on the day with suitable parking: the small bridge above the main A4085 bridge is good if there is space.

section: Pont y Gromlech to Gwastadnant Bridge
desc: Desperate and reactive paddling between large chock-stones down a spate ditch.
directions: Putin as high as you dare as you drive up Llanberis Pass from Nant Peris along the A4086 (be careful as footbridges across the river can become siphons). Takeout in or just upstream of Nant Peris before the river drops into the lake.

desc: For the very adventurous only, the walkin takes 1.5 hours and it needs to be raining at the time. You are rewarded for the hard work by a fun spate run.
directions: Requires an epic walkin. You can either skirt round the north across Bryn Melyn and Fan Dringarth, or walk up the river right of the Dringarth and simply keep going. Takeout at the reservoir.

desc: Can be used as an extension to the section above. Mellow water with a few weirs.
directions: Pakeout at the B4242 bridge in Resolven just off the A465. Takeout in Aberdulais, somewhere in town near the weirs just downstream of the A465 bridge that crosses high over the river.

section: Above footbridge to Upper Rawthey Confluence
desc: An alternative start to the Upper Rawthey. A 2.5m fall, a 7m slide and a tight difficult gorge that's probably blocked with trees!
directions:
From Rawthey Bridge carry on upstream and take a small road on the right. After 1km, turn right again, and then park where the road forks. Walk the boats down the left fork to a bridge over Needlehouse Gill and choose where's best to put on above this.
This would only be run if you intended carrying on down the Upper Rawthey.

desc: Low grade paddle with the odd weir.

section: Mennock to Glen Airlie Picnic Site
desc: Mainly gd 2, with a grade 3 rapid about halfwat down. Usually combined with the section downstream.
directions: Putin at Eliock Bridge, a minor road bridge just off the A76 just north of the hamlet of Mennock (just south of Sanquhar). Takeout at the Glen Airlie picnic site off the A76, or more usually continue downstream to combine this with the section downstream.

section: Tyn y Maes Bridge to Ogwen Bank
desc: A gorge with a series of tricky drops that are only sensible when the rest of the river is low. Scrappy stuff, the other sections are better.
directions: Takeout at Ogwen Bank off the A5 just south of Bethesda, or continue down straight into the next section. Putin at the next road bridge upstream.

desc: An excellent run, slightly easier and less continuous than the section above. Takeout just above the weir next to the green footbridge and walk up the left bank to the road.
directions: Putin at the A5 road bridge north of Besthesda (or continue down from the section above). Take the small dead-end road that follows the river left bank just downstream of the bridge. Follow this to the end of the road and park by the houses, it is easy to walk up here from the river.

desc: Combines with Green Field Beck to form the Upper Wharfe. Spate tree and fence filled steep ditch with plenty of tight rapids and small falls.
directions: Walk up the footpath above Oughtershaw village and put-on wherever looks sensible.

desc: A tough but awesome run. The gorge above the marked putin is extremely tricky and almost never has water in. The normal putin at Rhaeadr Du waterfall requires a walkin, from here down to the road bridge is demanding gd5.
directions: Takeout at the A486 road bridge near Maentwrog Power Station. Head up the small road along river right and walkin to Rhaeadr Du along the track down from Gellilydan.

desc: Low volume narrow gorges down to the normal starting point at Rawthey bridge: a decent addition to the standard run.
directions: From Rawthey Bridge carry on upstream and take a small road on the right. After 1km, turn right again, and then park where the road forks. Walk the boats down the left fork to a bridge over Needlehouse Gill and walk down the left bank of this tiny beck to the confluence. The marked takeout is at Rawthey bridge but most will combine this run with the popular section downstream and continue to Sedburgh.

desc: Would be a good paddle, but is spoilt by the constant tree portages. Pistyll Rhaeadr, Wales' tallest fall about a km above the putin is well worth a visit though.
directions: Takeout at the B4580 bridge in Llanrhaeadr-ym-Mochnant. Head upstream along the small road on river left, and the putin is down a small track at Tyn-y-wern about a km downstream of Pistyll Rhaeadr.

desc: Fun continuous run. Watch out for the low road and railway bridges that can be problematic in high water.
directions: To reach the putin head upstream from Abergwyngregyn to the carpark at Bont Newydd. Takeout just before reaching the sands, just downstream of the railway bridge: there is a carpark on river left a short walk from the river.

desc: A pleasant run, but watch out for low pipes across the river.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Blaencwm, just north of Treherbert. Takeout somewhere convenient in Porth, or continue straight onto the lower section to Hopkinson. There are plenty of bridges over the river, so would be easy to cut the run short if needed.

desc: A good finish to the upper Rhondda Fawr or the Rhondda Fach. Highlight is a series of semi-natural ledges under the railway bridge. Takeout river left just above Hopkinstown.
directions: Putin somewhere convenient in Porth, or paddle down from the section above or the Rhondda Fawr. Takeout at the carpark just off the A4058 in Hopkinstown.

desc:
Steep, narrow, committing ditch. You will need climbing gear, although there is an established rope to abseil down to below the two large falls that make up the portage. Be prepared, the level can rise quickly and the gorge is not easy to escape from.

From the putin paddle through the bog to the first set of small rapids. Portage river right immediately after a steep, rocky forked drop, as below here are two large falls onto rock. A short but difficult walk leads to a small tree with a fixed rope. Abseil in, careful not to drop any kit in the river. The first gorge is three distinct falls, with the second gorge around the corner culminating in "big boof", left line recommended. The river mellows for a few hundred metres before the takeout river left, just as you emerge from the trees. Note there are ongoing forestry works, so watch out for machinery.
directions: Put in just south of the windfarm at Cripiau Nantmelyn (just east of Pontarfynach along small roads, or via Arch Forestry car park) at a small bridge over the river. Reach the takeout by heading up the track on river left from the bridge just upstream of the confluence with the Mynach.

desc: Mostly low grade run, but lots of big weirs make this more interesting.
directions: Put in from Roch Valley Way in Rochdale, and take out at the Car Park at the end of Gigg Lane, Bury.

desc: Rarely paddled spate ditch Wear trib with a few waterfalls including a 4-5m fall which looks quite photogenic. Get out at Eastgate Bridge or continue onto the Wear.
Set in the steep wooded Rye valley, flows fast off the Yorkshire moors after recent rain. Beware of the tree lined banks in high water.
directions: Put in at the road bridge in Hawnby and get off in Helmsley. Flat below here until the Derwent.

section: Llyn y Fan Fach to Blaenau
desc: Similar but slightly easier than the nearby Haffes, an excellent run.
directions: Takeout at the village of Blaenau. If you are lucky the track will be open and you can drive up the river right bank to putin at Llyn y Fan Fach, it you can't get through you'll have to walk it.

desc: An odd man-made river, mostly flat, but loads of weirs to shoot, some of which can be tricky.
Fun grade 2 run, with a harder grade 3 section at the end as you approach the Usk confluence. Watch out for a sloping weir under a bridge halfway down the run.
directions: Takeout at the Usk in Sennybridge: take the turning into the Army barracks and then head down a small road just to the right of the barracks next to the river. The hardest rapid is at the confluence with the Usk: it is difficult to scout from the river so worth taking a look from the A40 road bridge before you get on. To reach the putin head south along the A4215 and then take a minor road through Cefnfedw to a bridge at Heol Senni.

desc: A full-on 200m blast. Above this section there is reputedly a 2km of grade 5/6 gorge if you fancy trying your luck.
directions: Takeout at Trericket Mill bridge just before the confluence with the Wye (just off the A470 between Llyswen and Erwood). From here simply walk 200m up the river and have a quick blast down.

desc: Very rarely run trib of the Tees Greta. Mostly fast flowing grade 2/3, but a serious gorge at Trough Heads contains spikes and siphons may need portaging.
directions:
Use the track up from Gilmonby to put-in around Bar Gap or higher. Alternatively put-in on Ease Gill on the Tan Hill round if water levels allow.
Get out after the Greta confluence at Gilmonby Bridge, or continue down the Greta for a long day's paddle!

desc: A series of about 5 drops/slides in the middle of Healey Dell Nature Reserve. Trees can be problematic.
directions: Follow the footpaths in Healey Dell and put in as high as safe to do so (up to the viaduct). Take out by the Rangers office.

section: Woodland Fell to Bedburn Beck Source
desc: Spate ditch in Hamsterley Forest. Mostly grade 2/3 but with one large fall (Blackling Hole) which can be run just as a park-and-huck in lower levels than needed for the rest of the beck.
directions: Use the Forest Drive in Hamsterley after paying the 3 toll. Park at Blackling Hole and walk up as high as you can be bothered. Take out at the car park near the Grove or carry on down Bedburn Beck.

section: Stock Ghyll Force to Rothay Confluence
desc: A stunt in the middle of Ambleside! Two big falls at the start which have been run, but rarely cleanly. A series of slides and falls follow down into the town, before flattening out on to the Rothay.
directions: Obvious if you're in Ambleside, just follow the river up as a high as you want to go. Either take out in Ambleside, or continue onto the Rothay.

section: Stonesdale Lane Bridge to Swale Confluence
desc:
Small, steep trib of the Upper Swale with plenty of small drops, fences and a short walled-in gorge containing some siphons near the end. Finishes with Currack Force waterfall which has a very shallow landing in all but spate levels.
Thanks to Dave Peel for info.
directions:
In high water put-in at road bridge on Stonesdale Lane when driving towards Tan Hill. Also possible to put in from bridleway about 1km further down the valley with a short walk-in.
Either take-out above Currack Force or carry on down the Swale where it merges just below Rainby Force (although easy to get out and run Rainby too).

desc: A fast spate stream, watch out for trees and wires across the river.
directions: The A470 runs along the river between the two reservoirs. Putin at the A4059 bridge just downstream of Beacons reservoir, and takeout at a small footbridge and layby off the A470 just before entering the Cantref reservoir.

desc: A good paddle with lots of fences to dodge. Although the overflow out from the reservoir at the putin has been run, it angered the water authority bailiffs so is best not repeated.
directions: Putin just downstream of the Cantref reservoir: take a small turn off the A470 into the waterworks and head down to the river. Takeout just downstream of the the minor road bridge before Llwyn-on reservoir.

desc: A good run, with an excellent gorge between nasty weirs. Watch out for Abercraf weir on a left-hand bend not far from the putin: it needs to be portaged early on river right. It can be inspecting by walking through the children's playground in the village. A great gorge follows before a double weir under a bridge just downstream of Ystradgynlais and the confluence with the Giedd. This can be difficult to stop above and so may be worth inspecting before you putin. A few easier weirs lead down the takeout on river right at the Twrch confluence.
directions: Putin along a footpath on river left at the upstream A4067 bridge in Abercraf. Takeout on river right at the confluence with the Twrch (between Ystragynlais and Ystalyfera).

desc: A beautiful touring section with no nasties.
directions: Takeout at the A482 bridge at Lampeter. Putin at Pont Gogoyan, a minor road bridge just east of Llanddewi-Brefi just downstream of the confluence with Afon Brefi.

desc: A good touring run with no nasties, with one grade 3 rapid just upstream of the takeout bridge at Maesycrugiau that you can get out above or below.
directions: Putin at the A482 bridge at Lampeter. Takeout just above or below the grade 3 drop at the bridge in Maesycrygiau, along minor roads just north-west of Llanllwni.

desc: A scenic trip through woodland with continuous grade two rapids and a large weir.
directions: Putin at the A382 road bridge just NE of Chagford. Takeout at Steps Bridge, the B3212 road bridge between Doccombe and Dunsford.

desc: Fun grade 1 run, with the grade 2 Fairnilee rapid at the end to round the trip off.
directions: Takeout at the A707 bridge at Fairnilee Farm, where the B7060 joins the A707. Putin at the minor road bridge just off the A707 at Peel (near the A72/A707 jct).

desc: Flat touring run with a couple of weirs. You can choose to get on above or below the grade 2 Fairnilee rapids just after the bridge at putin.
directions: Takeout at the bridge near St Boswells, and putin where the B7060 and A707 meet at the bridge at near Fairnilee Farm.

desc: Pool-drop run: flat sections with the occasional rapid. Highlight is Mackerstoun rapid (gd2/3), islands in mid-stream mark the start. Watch out for the weir just before the takeout: inspect/portage river right.
directions: Putin at the bridge just east of St Boswells. Takeout at a layby off the A699 just upstream of the main bridge in Kelso.

desc: Pleasant grade 1 paddling with a few small rapids and weirs.
directions: From Kelso to Berwick is a long full-day trip, but there are plenty of alternative putin/takeouts so the trip length can be adjusted to suit.

desc: Very hard series of waterfalls, some of which go nicely, others which don't!
directions: Take out at the Ingleton car park for the waterfall walk. Either walk up from here or drive up Thronton Lane until it meets the river again.

desc: A fun run whose difficultly depends very much on the levels. Starting with 2km of grade 3/4 the run hots up after reaching a 1.5m horseshoe weir. Downstream is hard grade 4 and two grade 5 falls. The 2nd grade 5 is about 50m above the takeout bridge, and it is easy to walk up and have a quick look-see before you get on.
directions: Takeout at the B4403 bridge in Llanuwchllyn, at the SW end of Llyn Tegid near Bala. To reach the put-in head upstream along a steep road on river right to Talardd and get-on at the the bridge.

desc: Easy water from the ford leads to a 2nd ford 500m downstream which will need portaging unless the river is high. From here the water is mellow to the road bridge halfway down, watch out for the fence hanging under the bridge. Downstream just after a stone bridge you enter the Twrch gorge, containg 4 distinct grade 3 rapids. After the gorge, the river is easy to the takeout.
directions: Takeout at the carpark on river right just downstream of the A458 road bridge at Foel. To reach the putin head upstream on river left along a minor road. Cross to river right at the first bridge (a possible alternative putin) and head upstream for a few km until there is a ford across the river just off the road near Dl-y-gaseg.

desc: Walk-in to the 6m waterfall at Dorwen: this has been run but usually at low levels. Downstream is bouncy water to a short narrow gorge which should be inspected as the exit drop is tricky. Once the river opens back out watch out for serious grade 6 fall that pops up just after a RH bend. Portage along the ledge on river right. The river eases off downstream until the takeout.
directions: Takeout in Ystradowen at a bridge down a small road off the A4068 just south of Cwmllynfell. It is problematic to work your way upstream to the putin: if possible, drive up the roads on river left however these are often closed because of the quarry work. Alternatively, head up the rough track on river right as far as you can and then continue upstream on foot. You want to get on at the 6m waterfall just north of Dorwen.

desc: A relaxed touring paddle. You will want to time your run with the tide: the last 5km will be much easier if timed to be just after high tide, but be quick otherwise you'll have to struggle through the mud banks to get out.
directions: Putin at the quayside in Carmarthen itself, or follow the B4300 out of Carmarthen along river left and access the river from a layby near Wenallt. Takeout at Llansteffan: either from one of the carparks or the boat house itself.

desc: Fairly flat and meandering upper section of the Ure.
Cruisy grade 2 run with no nasties that is good for introducing beginners to moving water.
directions: Putin at the upstream outskirts of Brecon just above the weir. Takeout at the bridge on the minor road off the A40 heading towards Talybont-on-Usk. Parking is a bit tight as you have to just tuck the car into the roadside on the river-right side of the bridge. A stile leads into the field on upstream river-right from which you can access the river just above the bridge.

desc: Combined with the section above is the classic Usk run. The ledge drop on the LH bend about 100m below the putin can be sticky, but other than this a no-nasties run, with good playholes in flood. Takeout on river right just below the weir under the bridge.
directions: Putin at Llangynidr bridge or from the section above, accessing the river from river-left side of the bridge and parking up the hill on the outskirts of the village. Takeout at the A4077 bridge at Crickhowell: there is a convenient layby on river-right just upstream of the bridge itself.

desc: Exploratory paddling in the Cheviots: starts with a 10m fall followed by lots of little grade 3/4 gorges.
directions: Access to the putin is via a forestry track that branches off the minor road up the Coquet at NT860114. The track passes two small farms marked as Trows and Rowhope on the OS map. Cross the ford (OK for cars at medium 0.6 gauge flows, but take care at higher levels) and follow the track up to park at the fork (NT880142). To access Davidson's Linn follow the left fork on foot, across a locked gate, and uphill through the forest for about 1.5km. After the gradient starts a slight decline take a descending path on the right for 500m to Davidson's Linn. Takeout at the confluence with the Coquet at Shillmoor.

desc: A touring run best done in low to medium flows due to the 3 weirs.
directions: Putin from the carpark near the bridge in Pontrobert, and takeout at the A490 bridge.

desc: Relentless choss with it's fair share of branches thrown in to make sure it stays exciting. The first 500m is particularly tree ridden and it might be worth walking round.
directions: At Merrivale there is a small bridge just upstream of the main road with good parking. The takeout has far less parking, so best to leave one car here and the rest at the top.

desc: Usually paddled as an extension to the section downstream, there's a couple of weirs to contend with, and one pretty gorge with a surprise at the end.
directions: There's a carpark at the takeout.

desc: Normally combined with the Tavy, this is a fun run which starts off gently and builds up to continuous low-end grade three, with one notable slot. There's one harder grade 3 on the Tavy, just below the confluence.
directions: There's a car park next to the river at Bedford Bridge. Take out at Denham Bridge on the Tavy.

desc: Fast flowing, low grade run in pleasent countryside.
Tree infested ditch starting below a big spillway off the dam.
directions: Put-in at the reservoir where there's parking for walkers. Take out at the Picknic site in Wolsingham off the B6296 or carry on down the Wear.

desc: Spate trib of the Yorkshire Esk. Lots of boulder garden type rapids, but beware of trees. Nelly Ayre Foss can be run in high water if putting in above the road.
directions:
Either put in where the beck goes under the road at New Wath Bridge in Scar Wood, or continue up the valley and walk down the path from Hunt Ho to where Wheeldale Beck joins.
Get out at Beck Hole at the confluence with Eller Beck.

desc: Fun gd3/4 run. Watch out for a footbridge after the caravan park, this is the takeout. Get out above the bridge on river right and carry up to a pub carpark. Downstream is steep scary stuff, best avoided.
directions: Putin at Barbrook, clambering down to the canalised river. Takeout at Lynbridge, a footbridge near a pub about a km downstream. Below this the river becomes heinous.

desc: Fun continuous grade 3 run. Watch out for two tight slots below 3 ledge drops just after the railway bridge.
directions: Takeout at Okehampton Castle where there is plenty of parking. Putin just below the dam, reached by heading west along the B3260 from the castle.

desc: Continuous spate run: the first 2km are the hardest as the river drops over a series of limestone ledges. Can be scouted from the road on the way up, so you can then blast down.
directions: Takeout at Hubberholme road bridge. The road heads upstream alongside the river so you can scout on the way. When the road swings away from the river at High Bank take a small LH turn and get-on at the bridge you reach almost immediately (at the end of the road before the farm buildings).

desc: An interesting addition to the Upper Swale in high water. Continuous grade three with plenty of rapids hidden round blind bends.
directions: Take the left turning up a small road west of Hoggarths Bridge, follow to the end and put in next to the farm yard. The beck ends at the confluence with the Upper Swale, which you'll want to paddle as well unless it's massive!

desc: Fun grade 2 run with 1 grade 3+ ledge drop about 1km from the putin.
directions: Putin at the B4416 bridge just off the A494 at Bont Newydd. Takeout just downstream of Dolgellau at the A493 bridge.

desc: An excellent run in decent levels. The harder grade 4 drop is at the takeout, just below the bridge in Rhayader. Takeout after the drop on river right.
directions: Takeout in Rhayader, just downstream of the B4518 bridge on river right after Rhayader Falls. Putin at Llangurig at the minor road bridge (turn off the A44 at the church).

section: Llyswen bridge to Hay on Wye
desc: Pleasant and easy touring run.
directions: Putin in Llyswen just upstream of the bridge on river right. Takeout in Hay-on-Wye: access is a little awkward but there is a footpath on either river left or right just downstream of the bridge.

desc: Possibly the best whitewater in the Peak District? Key feature is a fun grade 3 gorge in the middle of the run.
directions: Use the Car park opposite to Topley Pike quarry.

section: Ty du Bridge to Pont ar Yscir
desc: Fun little stream run. The weir 200m upstream of the takeout can be nasty: it's worth walking up to have a quick look before you get on.
directions: Takeout at the minor road bridge just upstream of the A40 bridge west of Brecon. To reach the putin keep heading upstream along the minor roads and putin at the small bridge by the farmyard.

desc: Popular grade 2/3 intermediate run.
directions: Putin at the B4575 bridge at Trawsgoed, and takeout at the minor road bridge just downstream of Llanilar.

section: Pont Glan y Wern to St Asaph
desc: Trees can be a problem over the first 5km, but after this is a pleasant touring section.
directions: The takeout is just off the A55 on the old A525 bridge at the  east side of St Asaph. Putin on the bridge on the little road from Denbigh to Waen.

desc: The classic section of the Dee. At low to medium levels a pool-drop run often used to introduce beginners to grade 3 paddling, at high to spate flows an excellent playrun. The hardest rapid (Town Falls) is right at the takeout under the main bridge in Llangollen: take care as the small weir just below this is reputed to contain metal spikes. Takeout ~100m after the bridge on river left. The rapids at Mile End Mill at the outskirts of Llangollen provide an early takeout (or simply a park and playspot) if you want to miss out Town Falls.
directions: Cross the river from the A5 at Berwyn along the B5103 and park for the putin in the carpark on river left. To reach Horseshoe Falls (a weir) walk 5 minutes upstream from the carpark, it is possible to walk out the back the highest parking area down a long grass slope to the river. Takeout in the carpark on river left just downstream of the main bridge in Llangollen. Alternatively, if you only have one car, Park in Llangollen, paddle up the canal to the put-in, then back down the river. Lovely.

desc: Small green wave at normal base levels, perfect for introducing beginners to moving water; the wave improves as the levels rise becoming increasingly fast and green up to about 0.8 - 0.9 when it closes out - use your own judgement whether to paddle or not. As the river continues to rise the wave greens out again before finally washing out above about 1.35m
directions: The weir is just downstream of Knightsford bridge, just east of Knightswick on the A44. Park in the lay-by on the river left and walk down to the weir.

desc: A few hundred metres of rapids between two weirs: park-n-play.
directions: Heading east from Lancaster along the A683 take a small left down to the river about 0.5km after passing under the M6. At the bottom of the hill, before crossing the bridge to Halton, park at the Lancaster University boathouse. The putin is reach by walking up the diused railway track on river left, and putting in below the top weir (don't go right up to the weir as it will mess with the fish counter).

desc: Worth doing if you're in the area, but not inspiring. Some bouncy rapids, and a few weirs to watch out for.
directions: The takeout is just off the A483 Chester to Wrexham road, reach the putin by heading up A541 towards Pontblyddyn and taking the furthest north small road to Hope.

desc: Decent run with the best rapids at Hazelbank, and good play waves just below Crossford Bridge at the takeout.
directions: Putin about 0.5km below Stoneybyres Power Station: a footpath goes down to the river from the A72 halfway between the junctions with the B7086 and B7018. Park in the layby on the opposite side of the road. Takeout at the A72 bridge in Crossford.

desc:
Excellent short blast, with plenty of playwaves, weirs and rapids. Runs at a variety of levels, often for days after rain as Windermere lake drains.
Backbarrow is the main event - an intimidating grade 4 under the road bridge, but with a nice big pool to mop up the pieces! You often have an audience from the hotel. The big weir after Backbarrow can be run at grade 5, but not recommended - there's a simple portage on river left.
Current recommendation is to get out river right above the roadbridge at Low Wood to avoid erosion of the bank below the bridge on river left.
directions: The put-in on river right on the small road just downstream of the bridge  (in Newby Bridge) is right on some salmon redds. Provided you won't touch/scrape over these as you launch, you'll be fine. If not, find an alternative put-in or perhaps a different river for the day.

desc: A relaxed touring run.
directions: Putin in Durham, there are a few carparks on river right just downstream of the A690 bridge. Takeout at Finchale Priory, which is a bit tricky to find: head up to Newton Hall and then follow signs out past the prison and keep going until you end up at Finchale Priory.

desc: A friendly green wave in low levels, it builds gradually, eventually turning into a sticky walled in monster when it gets too high. Look before you leap!
directions: Cross the bridge over the river right channel on Mill Lane, and park in the area on the left. To put on the water either seal launch from the bridge over the river left channel, or cross this bridge and put in from the footpath river left. Getting out take out river left below the weir and walk back over the bridge to the parking area.

desc: Flat sections interspersed by grade 2/3 rapids - enough of a gap to pick up the pieces if it all goes to pot. A great first taste of whitewater. Armathwaite weir is easily portageable on river left if needs be.
directions: A large car-park on river left just upstream of the bridge at Lazonby provides an ideal put-in, with steps down to the river. Takeout river right just below the bridge at Armathwaite.

desc: A scrappy technical gd3 run; expect trees and low bridges, and keep an eye out for the weir in Bontnewydd.
directions: Takeout at the A487 road bridge in Bontnewydd (there is a small carpark river left just downstream of the bridge). Putin at the lower of the two A4085 road bridges at Waunfawr.

desc: A classic. Short and sharp with a few falls, finishing with a flourish at Force Falls.
directions:
Putin at Scroggs weir which can be reached by heading down a small lane south of Kendal (the first turnoff after the coming off the A591 dual carriageway if you are heading north). Takeout on river right immediately after Force Falls underneath the A591 bridge (exit at the Sedgewick junction and head along the minor roads to the river).

If levels are low (below about 0.5) it is better to get in at Prizet Bridge as most of the interest is below this point (and it's mostly scrapey above here at these levels). There is limited parking here though, so you're best leaving most cars at the takeout.

desc: The classic section of the Conwy. The top half is an excellent grade 3/4 run (which can be done in it's own right, taking out at the second lay-by downstream of the bridge at Rhydlanfair on the A5 - Grid Ref:822528). Below here the water is unremarkable grade 3 with two distinctly harder drops. The first is a narrow chute leading to a twisting drop with an awkward landing. This can be viewed and easily portaged river left. The second (the "Gobbler") is a slightly easier S-bend, inspect river left. The portage for the Gobbler requires a bit of clambering around and a 2m seal launch, so is fun whether you run it or not! Take out river left about 1km below the Gobbler, keep your eyes peeled for white marker posts on river left. Go too far downstream and you end up at Conwy falls; the site of numerous mountain rescue team callouts where paddlers have not been vigilant enough. It is probably worth scouting the takeout before you get on.
directions: Putin at the A5 road bridge near the B4407 turn to Ysbyty Ifan. To reach the takeout head downstream along the A5, crossing from river left to river right. Park at the Conwy Falls cafe and takeout just above the B4406 road bridge and walk up the road to the cafe.

desc: Top quality continuous grade 3 read-and-run for almost its whole length.
directions: Takeout next to Caernarfon Castle once the Seiont meets the sea. To get to the putin head towards Llanberis from Caernarfon along the A4086. At Llanrug head down towards the river, and take the small right turn just after crossing the river. There are a few places along this single track road to park and access the river.

desc: An excellent continuous grade 2/3 blast. The hardest drop (gd4) is just downstream of the putin, and there are a couple f weirs to keep an eye out for. Takeout after joining the Severn.
directions: Takeout in Llanidloes at the B4518 bridge just off the A470. To reach the putin head upstream along the B4518 then head down a small left to the dam. Getin as close to the dam as possible.

desc: Short and sweet continuous blast of a run. "Gorge" is a slight misnomer as the entire run is escapable & inspectable on river left where a path runs along the bank. Can also inspect from the road on river right, there is a decent spectator point river right by the largest single drop about halfway down (known as the "Breaker")
directions: The putin is at a large layby about a mile from Beddgelert along the A498 towards Porthmadog. The takeout is at Pont Aberglasyn, at the junction of the A4085/A498. It is possible to takeout on river left just before the bridge, but an easier takeout is 50m upstream on river right where you can hop over the wall back onto the road. There is no parking at the takeout: park at the putin and walk back up.
