desc: Perfect intro to moving water for beginners. Gently moving flat water with a couple of small weirs which allow for an intro to playing. Can easily be extended by continuing on to one of the bridges downstream.
directions: Put-in river left on Goosemore Lane. Shuttle up the A638, turning off immediately after you turn left onto the A620. Park in the large car park next to the river.

desc: Scene of the annual "Tyne Tour". Highlight is Warden's Gorge, a short 100m of bouncy grade 3 with a good slab drop at the end.
directions: Putin at Chollerford bridge on river left. Takeout on river right at the landing area just upstream of the weir in Hexham.

desc: An excellent committing gorge run, gets sketchy in flood. Can be inspected on the way up from the dismantled railways that criss-crosses its path.
directions: Takeout at the B4416 bridge just off the A494 at Bont Newydd (just east of Dolgellau). Putin at the minor road bridge at the bridge just off the A494 at Dolddeuli, a couple of kilometres upstream of Rhydymain.

desc: The difficulty in this section, if any, lies in the first kilometre, where the river is narrower and trees may be an issue. The remainder is flat and meanders through the scenic valley bottom. The occasional fence may be lurking in the lower section.
directions: The put-in is from the carpark on river right, just upstream of the roadbridge. For the takeout, river left above Southwaite Bridge is the best option, not far from a small parking area.

desc: Often paddled in conjunction with the top section, this part of the river conveniently contains all the whitewater interest if you're after a quick blast down a shorter section. The run starts with a small weir - beware the towback in high levels. The best section of this run is the final kilometre through the town, where the river yields a number of bouncy grade 3's with nice surf waves at certain levels.
directions: Parking is possible on river left above the roadbridge, adjacent to the weir. Take-out just after the confluence from the Derwent, river right just after the first bridge you pass under. There is a huge car park next to a play area where you can leave your car.

desc: A good play run when up. Lots of weirs, but most are friendly.
directions: Putin at the smaller bridge just upstream of the main A544 bridge at Llanfair Talhaiarn. Takeout at the narrow bridge at Bontnewydd.

desc:
The reputation of this classic testpiece is probably more fearsome than it is in reality, but it should be respected as a committing run due to the fact that the second half is in a boxed-in gorge.

The first half of the run is a good warmup before you reach Fairy Falls, probably the hardest individual rapid on the run: inspect and portage if necessary on the left bank. From here you can escape to the road on river left or continue into a boxed in canyon.

200m downstream of Fairy Falls is the "Pipeline": you are already committed by the time you reach it but can hop out on rocks on river left to pick a line.

The final rapid of note an uninspectable horizon line: take this 1.5m ledge drop roughly in the centre. The takeout is obvious as you pop out of the canyon to a calm pool and the confluence with the Lledr.
directions:
Takeout at the pool at the confluence of the Conwy and Lledr at the A470 road bridge just outside Betws-y-Coed.

To reach the putin continue on the A470 away from Betws-y-Coed and take the first left to cross the Lledr and head up the Conwy. It is possible to stop and scout Fairy Falls on the way up. Park at the large layby and walk down to the river.

desc: Small bit of grade three at the start, with a surfable wave. The gradient then eases off throughout the run.
directions: Put on from the bridge at Wolsingha. Takeout river left after passing under the A68, at the minor road bridge.

desc: Pleasant touring paddle. One natural weir step towards the end of the run can reach gd3 in flood.
directions: Putin where the A458 crosses the river at Llanerfyl from the little road heading upstream. Takeout in the town of Llanfair aereinion at the bridge.

desc: Gentle low grade paddle in the central Lakes encompassing Grassmere Lake and Rydal Water.
directions:
Put-in either on Grassmere Lake or on the river above.
Take out at the final weir or on Lake Windermere.

desc: Good touring run, with just 1 weir to watch out for.
directions: Putin at Edisford Road Bridge, just west of Clitheroe. Takeout at Ribchester School.

desc: Mellow touring run through beautiful countryside.
directions: Putin at Grinton bridge. Takeout in Richmond, at the carpark on river left downstream of the bridge.

desc: A classic section with easy access. The narrow gorges are still fun in low water and the "The Strid" becomes a monster in epic water. Two weirs after Killington Bridge can be avoided by getting out at Killington Bridge itself - this is recommended if you have inexperienced paddlers in your group.
directions: Putin at the Crook of Lune bridge, along a small road just off the B6257 just south of the M6. There is no parking at the bridge, and the residents have asked that you don't drive down the narrow lane to drop off boats. Park at the end of the lane and carry the boats down to the river - possibly paddling Low Gill on the way. Takeout on river left about 300m downstream of the Rawthey confluence. A bridleway leads up to track back to the road where there is a large layby to park.

desc: Good beginner's or play run through little sandstone gorges.
directions:
There is easy access to the river from Sorn, Catrine, Auchincruive, Ayr, but the best whitewater is between the villages of Mauchline and Stair. Putin at the old road bridge between Mauchline and Catrine, turning west off the A76 just before it crosses the river. Takeout at the bridge in Stair.

If paddling from alternative access points, watch out for a few tricky weirs: one in Catrine, and another by the university in Ayr.

desc: Fun grade 2 leads down to a short gorge, the entrance marked by a footbridge. The gorge is grade 2/3, with 'Banana Slide' at it's exit.
directions: Putin at the village of Yarrowford, parking in the layby on the A708 at the western end of the village. Takeout 3km downstream at General's Bridge, where the B7039 crosses the river. It's an awkward scramble up. Alternatively continue onto the Ettrick and takeout in Selkirk.

desc: Pleasant run with no nasties. Can be combined with the gorge below to provide interest for a mixed group of beginners and experts. Hardest section is about a mile above Beddgelert as the river passes under a bridge, you can stop and take a peek on the shuttle to confirm levels are OK.
directions: Putin from any of a number of laybys off the A498 next to Llyn Dinas, a few miles north of Beddgelert. Takeout either in Beddgelert itself, or from another layby off the A498 about a mile south of Beddgelert before the gorge.

desc: A popular grade 3 classic. That this is one of the few UK rivers with a sensible access agreement. Paddling is permitted year round, but in Nov-Dec the level must be above the white marker on the bridge to avoid damaging salmon spawning redds. Whilst the white line may possibly be positioned a bit high, it corresponds to a level of approx 1.41m on the Low Briery Gauge. The river itself changed considerably in the December 2015 floods, but is still a classic, even if some rapids have been lost and new ones formed.
directions: Putin at Threlkeld bridge, along a small road off the A66 just east of Threlkeld (signposted to the Youth Centre and Castlerigg Stone Circle). Takeout on river right at the climbing wall carpark in Keswick. Alternatively paddle another flatish 1.5km down to onto the Derwent and takeout on river right just before the suspension footbridge at Portinscale.

desc: An easy spate run, popular with open boaters.
directions: Putin at Alston, parking near the tourist railway. Takeout at Slaggyford where a small road bridge crosses the river. It is possible to extend the run in various ways, even paddling 24km all the way down to Haltwhistle.

desc: Fun grade 3 run with a couple of challenges. A large island warns of the lead-in to Rawford bridge (gd4), which is followed by a nasty weir.
directions: Putin at the bridge just south of Ulpha or continue from the section above. Takeout immediately downstream of Duddon Bridge on the river left.

desc: A series of three difficult falls, runnable in high water.
directions:
Park in the car park on the northern bank and walk down to the road and onto the footpath back upstream for the first fall.
Get out river left after the final fall and follow the footpaths back to the car park.

desc: Fun run with a few good playspots in good water. Note that the run down from further upstream at Llanpumsaint is not recommended due to trees.
directions: Putin on the Afon Duad at a small bridge in Cynwyl Elfed (on the A484 just upstream of its confluence with the Gwili), near the "Rock and Fountain" pub. Takeout just east of Carmarthen at the last bridge before the confluence with the Towy (just downstream of the main A40 bridge, on Abergwili Road).

section: Wath Brow Bridge to Low Mill
desc: The river is a pleasant run through fields and a couple of villages. The gradient remains fairly consistent throughout keeping interest all the way. A couple of weirs in Egremont can be easily shot and only become nasty in the highest of water levels, when both can be portaged. Downstream of Egremont, a small broken weir can form a nice play-wave, getting really good at levels between 1.5 and 2m. Those wanting to extend the trip can continue on down to Braystones (or even to the Sellafield site), though the river is easier on this section.
directions: For the put-in, park in the large parking area just downstream and river right of the picturesque Wath Brow bridge. Drive southwards past Egremont, taking your first right after Thornhill to reach the take-out. Parking here is more limited.

desc: Starts off flat with the odd grade 2, then a good play wave followed by a bouldery grade 3 section.
directions:
Putin at the bridge near the museum between Deepcar and Thurgoland.

Take out at the road bridge in Oughtibridge. There are mixed messages on this but Sheffield Canoe Club's site is nearby and often suggested as an egress: however their car park is usually locked so unless you are a member I think it's best to use the road bridge.

An alternative is to extend the trip by 2km and continue to takeout at SK328916 (where the blue P&R letters are on the map).
Putin at Peebles. Takeout at Peel: the minor road bridge just off the A707 near the A72/A707 jct.

section: Glen Airlie Picnic Site to Drumlanrig
desc: Continuous gd 3 run. Watch out for trees, particularly in Drumlanrig gorge (gd 4) just before the takeout. Takeout river right just before Drumlanrig Bridge.
directions: Putin at the Glen Airlie Picnic site just off the A76 about 7km south of Sanquhar. Takeout at a minor road bridge near Drumlanrig Castle (follow the signs to the castle off the A76).

desc: Quite a mix of grades, perhaps best suited to a mixed ability group. The river is grade 2/3 for most of it's length with two harder drops. Cobdens Falls (4) opposite a hotel can be inspected river right and has a good footbridge for spectating. Pont Cyfyng (5) under the only road bridge on this section is tougher and can be portaged river left along the road before cutting back down through a farmer's field.
directions: Putin by parking along the road near Plas-y-Brenin near Capel Curig and walk the boats down a footpath to the end of the lake. The takeout is down the A5 towards Betws-y-Coed, park on next to the "Ugly House" on the left just before the A5 crosses the river.

section: Garscube Bridge to Kelvingrove Art Gallery
desc: Urban flat water boating with great views of Glasgow. Be careful at the first weir in particular, and enjoy the play-wave at the end.
directions: Putin at Garscube Bridge, where Maryhill Road (A81) crosses the Kelvin. Turn off the A81, and access the river near the entrance to Killermont Golf Club. Alternatively, you can putin at the Kelvindale Road bridge (just south of the canal bridge) which avoids Kelvindale weir. Takeout at the Kelvingrove Art Gallery at the southern end on Kelvingrove Park, or continue down to the Clyde.

desc: Fast bouncy fun. Watch out for a couple of pipes across the river above and below an obvious football pitch.
directions: The A4107 running inland from Port Talbot runs alongside the river. The putin is just off the main road at Cymer, and the takeout is near the junction with the B4287.

desc: Gentle grade 2 for the first 2km leads to some harder ledge drops and weirs before it eases again to the takeout. You can extend the trip by continuing onto the Elwy.
directions: Putin is just off the A544 south of Llanfair Talhaiam, with the takeout reached by wiggling along the backroads from the A548.

section: Ashgill Force to South Tyne Confluence
desc: Short steep trib of the Upper South Tyne containing five falls. Usually paddled as a diversion to the Tyne.
directions: Put on below Ashgill Force (it lands on rock). Continue down the South Tyne after the confluence.

desc: The classic gd2 run of the south-west, and an excellent introduction to whitewater for beginners. The first km down from Tarr Steps holds the best rapids.
directions: Putin at Tarr Steps, on the minor road between Hawkridge and Liscombe (south-east of Withypool). Takeout in Dulverton on river left just before the main bridge, using the public carpark rather than the limited parking by the river.

desc: The poor sibling to the section upstream, but runs at lower levels. A decent touring run or introduction for beginners. Watch out for a couple of weirs and takeout at Exebridge after the confluence with the Exe.
directions: Putin at Dulverton, at the concrete ramp on river left just upstream of the main road bridge. Please park in the public carpark rather than the limited space by the river. Takeout in Exebridge river left just upstream of the bridge: the pub don't mind you using their carpark but consider a post-trip beer.

desc: Mostly flat from Elterwater lake down to Skelwith Force (can portage river left). From there are occasional rapids down to Brathay Pool. It is possible to takeout here, or carry on down to the confluence with the Rothay and onto Windermere, heading across the lake to takeout at the pier.
directions: Lots of possible put-ins, or indeed paddle straight onto this run from Great Langdale Beck. The putin marked is at the carpark at the road bridge over Great Langdale Beck at Elterwater village. Alternatively find somewhere to putin at the lake, or below Skelwith Falls. Takeout at the pier on Windermere Lake, just outside Ambleside.

desc: Enjoyable bimble through pleasant countryside, beware of the occasional tree. The whitewater interest lies in the second half of the run where a few rapids liven up the approach to Calder Bridge. It is possible to continue past Calder Bridge, taking in some unusual sandstone gorges. Possible takeouts are a) at a public footpath which goes down to the river, or b) continuing through the Sellafield nuclear site down to the sea. Note that there are a couple of grade 4 rapids through Sellafield which are made all the more interesting by their unique location.
directions: Thornholme Farm can be reached from Calder Bridge by turning off the Cold Fell road as it zig-zags up a steep hill. There isn't much parking, but make sure to leave access for farm traffic. There is a large car park on your left as the Cold Fell road enters Calder Bridge.

desc: Relentless fun grade 3 with drops of 4 for the first ~1km especially in high water. Eases to grade 2/3 for the latter ~2km. It is possible to put in higher up if you want a warm up, you'll need to walk for it though.
directions: From Mosedale bridge, head north a matter of metres, before taking a left up the small road towards Swineside. There is a reasonable parking area at the put-in near Grainsgill Beck, but be careful if your car doesn't have much ground clearance!

desc: Small but continuous, with lots of trees to paddle around/over.
directions: Putin at the road bridge near Trecarne (a few km south of Camelford). Takeout at Penrose Bridge, just west of St Breward.

desc: Pleasant easy paddle until the stiff grade 5 gorge. This can be portaged, but is best inspected before getting on (from the road to Gaer-gerrig and the old A5). From here to the confluence is an excellent paddle with just a few weirs to keep an eye out for. The gnarly gorge is a good trip in it's own right, although you've got to catch the water levels just right.
directions: River runs alongside the A5 just west of Corwen. Takeout at Meardy, and putin at the first bridge west of Ty Nant.

desc: The best paddling comes in the form of a small gorge, about 1km after the put-in. This can reach 4 in spate, but at normal levels is a bouldery grade 3. The river eases off the closer to the takeout you get. Beware of trees.
directions: Shuttle along the A478. Turning off onto the B-road at Efailwen to reach the put-in at the bridge in Llangolman. Retrace your steps and take the right in the centre of Llandissilio onto a small lane that crosses the river at Llangwm. The road at the takeout is narrow so try to minimise leaving cars here... oh, and don't try driving through the ford if the river is up!

desc: Beautiful touring river. Only nasty is the weir in Haverfordwest itself, but you can takeout in the carpark just above this on river left to avoid it. Some of the broken weirs on the way down are great to play on at the right level, especially the Fishing lodge weir near Treffgarne
directions: Takeout in the large carpark by the weir in Haverfordwest itself. To reach the putin head north along the A40 towards Firshguard and at Wolfscastle turn off left up to Welsh Hook. Here it is possible to get on a small tributary that meanders down to the Cleddau itself.

desc: Good little river that passes through a series of fun mini-gorges. A few fences to watch out for - in particular in the upper reaches - but otherwise no nasties. Note that below Llangernyw the Cledwen becomes the Elwy.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Gwytherin (just east of Betws-y-Coed), and takeout at the bridge in Llanfair Talhaiam.

section: Garsdale Head to Bellow End Bridge
desc: Steep and continuous with regular bedrock falls including the infamous Lemmings drop which is notoriously difficult to stop in time to inspect.
directions: Putin at on of the many A684 bridges near Garsdale Station if there is enough water (it's obvious just by looking at the river, what you see is what you get). The section is best combined with the lower section of the river.

section: Bellow End Road Bridge to Sedbergh
desc: Lovely run with plenty of interest at the grade. One cheeky hole in particular has been known to catch a few people unawares. A weir about 1/2 way down is runnable, but worth keeping an eye out for as can be retentive at bigger levels.
directions: If driving upstream from the takeout in Sedbergh, put in at the first bridge the A684 crosses the river. The takeout if about 1km after the confluence with the Rawthey, on river right just below the A684 bridge just east of Sedbergh.

desc: Fun limestone gorges and ledge drops. A couple of weirs to watch out for: just before the second road bridge in Bontuchel and one near the takeout.
directions: Putin at the bridge in Cyffylliog, and takeout in Rhewl either at the main A525 bridge or the smaller bridge just upstream.

desc: Fun high water run, continuous interest all the way down with regular tricky drops to provide spice.
directions: Take out at the confluence with the Glaslyn in Beddgelert (or at the end of the Aberglasyn Gorge, which will be at a great level). To get to the putin head towards Carnarfeon from Beddgelert up the A4085. After 1.5 miles take a small left turn down towards the river and follow it to a small bridge over the river. Be subtle and leave as few vehicles here as possible as there is a farm right next to this bridge.

desc: A pleasant run suitable for beginners. The bridge opposite Foel Ddu 3km upstream of the marked putin can be used as an alternative but the run then includes a tricky fall and barbed wire across the river!
directions: Takeout at the A5 road bridge near the B4407 turn off to Ysbyty Ifan. To reach the putin head upstream along the B4407 and either putin at Ysbyty Ifan itself, or continue heading upstream until you can turn left down a narrow road to the river a few km further up. If you use the putin at Ysbyty Ifan please be considerate about changing: it's best to get changed before arriving as houses look out directly onto the parking area.

desc: Fairly fast grade two with the odd grade three rapid.
A good alternative to the upper Afan. The grade 4 rapid is at the putin just above Glyncorrwg, from here it is a fast grade 2/3 until it joins the Afan at Cymer.
directions: Takeout at the bridge in Cymer just downstream of the confluence with the Afan. Reach the putin by heading upstream to Gyncorrwg and get on just upstream of the town.

desc: Fun grade 2/3: builds up in excitement culminating in Bobbin Mill Rapid just before Spark Bridge.
directions: Putin at the south end of Coniston Water. There are a few lay-bys on the west side from where you can walk down to the water's edge. Takeout river right just downstream of the bridge in Spark Bridge.

desc: Fun sections of continuous grade 4, with a couple of grade 5 drops to watch out for!
directions: Putin at the A714 bridge at Arnimean (about 7km east of Barrhill). Takeout at the next A714 road bridge south-east towards Glen Trool, just before the confluence with the Water of Trool.

desc: Spate river with nice continuous grade 3/4 gorge at the start.

Fabulous grade 4 classic: continuous and isolated away from the road. Highlights in order of appearance are the "mad mile" (full-on in spate), Euthanasia Falls (slidey drop on a RH bend) and "Surprise Surprise!" (an awkward slot).
directions: Takeout at the National Park carpark at Newbridge. Putin at the carpark at Dartmeet.

desc: Hugely popular classic grade 2/3 often used to introduce beginners to whitewater.
directions: Putin at the National Park car park at Newbridge. Take out at the River Dart Country Park.

desc: Various play-spots around the weir depending on the level: on the weir canoe-shoot; the archimedes screw output; the water wheel tail-race.
directions: Park at the bridge to the east of Howsham village, then paddle up to the weir.

section: Red Rock Lane to Flood Prevention Barrage
desc: Shallow urban stream running from Worthington Lakes reservoir down towards Wigan town centre. Despite it's proximity to urban sprawl, it's not as built up as you'd think once you're down at river level. The river keeps a fairly rapid flow throughout, although it never gets above grade 2. Beware of fallen trees and branches.
directions: Follow the A49 north out of wigan, turning right onto the A5106 at a roundabout with an Esso garage. After ~1km, turn right onto Red-Rock Lane (B5239) at a mini-roundabout and you cross the river immediately. There is very limited parking here, but ~200m up the hill is a free car park. To find the take-out, retrace your steps back onto the A49, turn left Coppull Lane, and drive down to the river. There's plenty of parking here, but leave space at the bottom for other cars to turn round.

desc: An absolute classic. At the put-in is the gun-barrel run (gd5) - 100m of narrow siphon-filled mank for the brave. 500m of gd3 leads into Troutal gorge (gd5): portage river left. Fun, continuous grade 3 water leads down to Wallowbarrow gorge (continuous gd4+/5), inspect along the footpath on river right. The river then eases off for the last 2km down to Hall Bridge.
directions: Takeout at Hall Dunnerdale Bridge to the north of Broughton in Furness. To reach the putin head upstream to a picnic site by the river at Birks bridge (a disused bridge just off the road).

desc: An excellent bouncy run in high water. It is possible to get on at various bridges higher than the recommended putin, but the majority of it is flat and meandering with a liberal scattering of trees for good measure. Pretty though, if that's your bag.
directions: Putin at the disused road bridge just off the A487 at Dolbenmaen. Takeout up the steps river left, just upstream of the first road bridge in Llanystumdwy.

desc: Popular open boat trip, with the occasional weir to add spice!
directions: Takeout just above the weir at Brougham Castle and follow the public footpath to the lay-by just off the A66

desc: Fun continuous boulder rapids and drops. Hardest drop is a two-tier waterfall about halfway down.
directions: Putin at the village of Brendon. Please be considerate and change before you get there. Although it is possible to takeout at Watermeets, you'd be mad not to continue straight onto the section downstream and takeout at the sea.

desc: Excellent creeking run, with most of the action in one long gorge.
directions: Takeout in Lynmouth where the river enters the sea. Putin at Watermeet at the confluence with the Hoaroak: park on the A39 and carry down to the river.

desc: Classic narrow creeking. At high water watch out for the slot just downstream of a series of small ledges (~2km in). The run cranks up from here, culminating in the Erme gorge which starts under the railway viaduct. Inspect along the path on river right. Takeout at the footbridge in Ivybridge. Below about 0.63 on the gauge, it is recommended to park in Ivybridge and walk-in to the slot rapid, as above here starts to get scrapy.
directions: Takeout at the footbridge in the centre of Ivybridge where there is plenty of parking. Putin at the road bridge at Harford, a small village north of Ivybridge.

desc: Pleasant touring or beginners run.
directions: Lots of access/egress points on the run mean length can be adjusted to suit. Suggested putin is at Enzieholm Bridge, about 14km north of Langholm; takeout out at Langholm for a grade 1 trip, or continue downstream onto the next section (gd 2/3) to Hollows Bridge or Canonbie.

desc: Grade 1 down to Skippers Bridge. After the bridge is a 300m gd 3 rapid ('Skippers'), and a couple of gd 2/3 rapids round Dog and Irvine mid-stream islands (stay river right). Keep an eye out for 'The Slabs' (gd 3+) at Hollows Bridge, and decent rapids follow down to Canonbie.
directions: Putin in Langholm at the car park, which puts you straight into a canalised stretch that opens out to let you float through the town. Alternatively, putin just downstream at Skipper's Bridge. Takeout at the Canonbie, where you can park in the village hall car park.

desc: Fun classic section of the Esk: no nasties but watch out for trees.
directions: Park at the layby at the bottom of Hardknott Pass next to the track up to Brotherilkeld farm. Walk up the track towards the farm and take the footpath down to the river. Takeout at Forge Bridge, near Eskdale Green village.

desc: Unpromising start, but after 200m of ducking and diving through trees things improve. Golitha Falls are 2 successive fun gd4 drops, if you're not convinced at the putin walk down to have a look and see what you'd be missing.
directions: Putin at the Goliath Falls carpark, getting on just below the bridge from the footpath. Takeout at Treverbyn Mill, the twin bridges just east of St Neot.

section: Cattle grid to Pistyll y Cain
desc: A brilliant run. Flat down to the first bridge, after which it starts to steepen up. Another km further down you reach the harder stuff. Watch out for a stone arched bridge: a tricky fall lurks underneath with more just round the corner. A tricky gorge follows this, be careful as it ends in Pistyll y Cain, a monster waterfall that you will need to portage (river right). It is possible to get out here, but easier to join the Mawddach and carry on down its lower gorge to takeout just below public toilet falls.
directions: Takeout at the public toilets in Ganllwyd, from here there is easy access down the bank to the river. To reach the putin head north along the A470 and take a small right at Bronaber and keep going until you reach a bridge over the river.

section: Binney Bank to Low Gelt Bridge
desc: Run of continued interest through some narrow gorges with the spicy combination of sparse eddies and a high risk of trees to keep you on your toes.
directions: Put in at Binney Bank, or if you don't value your warm-up opportunities, hop in at Hynam Bridge to drop straight into the thick of it. Take out at Low Geltbridge, just off the A69.

desc: A collection of weirs coupled with MCC's slalom site. Possible to extend the trip with more weirs in high water by starting as far up as Whalley Bridge or getting out as far down as Stockport. In spate some weirs will need portaging.
A fun trib of the Usk. Inspect the weir just downstream of Llangenny on the way up as it is very obvious from the road, this is the only weir to watch out for, especially at high flows.
directions: Takeout river left at the main A40 road bridge (just can park at the village hall). To reach the put-in head up small roads along river left, cross the river at Llangenny and then stay right until you reach the Lower Cwm Bridge (over a trib) from where it is <200m to the main river.

desc: Watch out for a couple of weirs, especially the one at Houston (portage/inspect river left). The main fall is about 2km in, followed by a km of fast shallow gd3 before it eases off.
directions: To reach the putin take the minor road west from Bridge of Weir towards Quarriers Village (heading upstream under the railway bridge). Putin after about 1km, carrying the boats down through the fields to the river. Takeout at the small bridge in the Craigsend estate, just east of Houston.

desc: A fun easy spate run. Don't try to get on any higher than the recommended putin, upstream is filled with trees.
directions: Takeout in the harbour at Fishguard. To reach the putin head up the Gwaun along the B4313 and putin at Pontfaen. Sometimes the upper half of the river can be a little tree choked: an alternative put-in is the bridge halfway down at Llanychaer.

desc: Continuous grade three boulder garden spate beck through a wooded valley in West Yorkshire.
directions: Put in at Black Dean road bridge, take out in Hebden Water.

desc: Great run: steep slabs at the start, plenty of grade 3 and then a straightforward but bigger fall towards the end. Beware of this one in bigger levels as there aren't many eddies above it!
directions: Takeout at Mealbank bridge, on the B6480 just north of Wray. Putin at the bridge near Lowgill village: go across the first bridge across the Hindburn and 100m later is another bridge over a small side beck at a sharp bend: from here there is access down to the confluence.

section: Camddur Bleiddiad gorge to Llanwrtyd Wells
desc: Putin below Camddwr Bleiddiad gorge to a fun series of gd4 drops down to Abergwesyn bridge (for a shorter run it is possible to takeout here). Below here the water is generally easier, but there is a good short stretch that has another 4 major drops before the river eases until the takeout.
directions: Takeout at the A483 bridge in Llanwrtyd Wells. To reach the putin head upstream along small roads to Abergwesyn where the road crosses to river left. Continue up the river left bank for about 3km to a lay-by and walk down to get on below Camddwr Bleiddiad gorge. The gorge itself is nasty, so make sure you don't get-on too high.

desc: Huge waterfall (Crammel Linn) at the start, get in above or below depending on skill and bravery levels! Rest of the run is grade 3 with sloping weirs. Higher water brings
directions: Put in at the waterfall after driving along the single track road and walking down the boggy path. Get out at the stepping stones above the village of Gilsland.

desc: The full run from Ramsbottom contains a collection of weirs to shoot. The Burrs site itself has been developed for paddlers, with a collection of playable waves and stoppers. Careful of the big weir at the top of the Burrs site in high water. The stopper can become nasty.
directions: The put-in from Ramsbottom is upstream of the main road bridge. The Burrs site itself can be used as a take-out, or a base to do laps.

desc: The first 200m is fairly tree ridden and may be worth portaging if super high. The exit to Kentmere Tarn can also be a bit tree-eey but the flow isn't fast so portaging is OK. The remainder of the run is constantly moving so provides continual interest throughout. The highlight is a few hundred metres of grade 3, not far after a pretty mini-gorge. If you don't plan to run the rapid at Scroggs bridge (grade 4), it might be worth scouting your take-out eddy on the way up.
directions: Take the small turning in Staveley signposted to Kentmere. When the road crosses to river left as you head north, you've reached Scroggs Bridge, the takeout. Continue northwards up the valley until you reach Kentmere. Parking here is very limited, so be discrete and try not to block passing places. A gate and small stile give access to the river on river left.

desc: Two grade 4 rapids and four significant weirs. The run starts with a bang at Scroggs Bridge, putting in below is possible if you'd rather a more sedate warm up. A couple of weirs appear through Staveley. The undoubted highlight of the section is the rapid through the Cowan Head complex. A weir drops into a long steep powerful (and really fun) rapid.
directions: Take the small turning in Staveley signposted to Kentmere. When the road crosses to river left as you head north, you've reached Scroggs Bridge, the put-in. Driving south from Staveley, look for signs to the left to Burneside. There's three options so don't worry if you miss the first one. Downstream of the bridge (river right) in Burneside is a small park and area for parking.

section: Pont y Pant to Beaver Pool
desc: Starts off with Pont-y-Pant falls, a long technical rapid ending in a slide. If you're feeling like you'd rather have a warm-up before tacking this, it is possible to put in below by carrying 150m down the road on river left.  A few more good grade 4 rapids follow before the 'minger', which marks the start of a fun 200m gorge. The 'minger' forms a chunky hole (portage over the rocks hard left) at anything above medium levels, but when it is high, a chicken line with a nice boof line opens up down the portage line. A small bridge (5304'06.0"N 350'09.8"W) marks an alternative takeout half-way, or continue down, being sure to get out river right to portage Viaduct falls  a long manky siphon filled rapid that has been run but is not recommended.
directions: Takeout just south of Betws-y-Coed on the A470 at the confluence with the Conwy (the same takeout as the Fairy Glen). To get to the putin continue up the A470 away from Betws-y-Coed to Pont-y-Pant bridge (a small bridge just off the main road next to a restaurant). Don't forget to drop a few quid in the honesty box for use of their land for parking.

desc: Bouldery grade 2/3 rapids in pleasant woodland.
directions:
To put-in, take the public footpath down to the river at Crookwath Bridge.
Get out on the right bank above Brougham Castle Bridge.

Alternatively, for a shorter run get on at Askham Bridge and get off at the A6 Bridge at the entrance to Lowther Caravan Site.

desc: The rapid under the disused road bridge is by far the hardest on the section. A weir immediately above this rapid gets terminal in high water, but it is possible to put in between the two if you fancy the rapid but not the weir. The river is pretty grade 2 from here on down, making you forget about the roaring motorway in the same valley.
directions:
The best put-in is an old road bridge over the river, just to the north of where A685 crosses the M6. Walk upstream on river right to paddle the drop, or downstream on river left to put-in below.

To reach the takeout, drive south along the A685 forking left onto the B6257. As you pass under a bridge just south of the M6 there is an old viaduct on your left with a small lane running under it. The takeout is at the bridge just down this lane, however the residents have asked that you don't park at the bridge itself. Park at the end of the lane and walk back to your car... or, carry on downstream!

desc: A fun touring run: there are a few weirs which are mostly friendly but one requires care in high water.
directions: Putin just downstream of Pontypool just downstream of the A4042 bridge: there is a minor road bridge as you head towards New Inn. Takeout after the confluence with the Usk at the B4236 bridge just south of Caerleon. The river is tidal at this point so it is probably worth timing your run correctly.

desc: A superb run. There are two good grade 5 feature drops before reaching the awesome Rhaeadr Mawddach waterfall, portage river right down a track to the confluence with the Gain. Two further gorges follow: the first is known as the "three nasties" (scout river left), the 2nd fun but easier. The run finishes with a bang with a 2m waterfall at the confluence with the Eden, then watch out for the weir immediately below. Takeout just after the next rapid "Public Toilet Falls" (PTF) up the bank on river right to the carpark by the toilets.
directions: Takeout at the public toilets in Ganllwyd, from here there is easy access down the bank to the river. A OS map is useful to find the putin along a maze of small roads to Pont Aber-Geirw.

section: Sgwd Clun-gwyn falls to Dinas Rock
desc: A precarious seal launch just under the main falls at the putin gives you possibly 5 paddle strokes before a 4m boof: a great start. Shortly afterwards round a LH bend the lead-in to the main waterfall starts, care needs to be taken to stop and scout it early as there are no eddies within direct line of sight with the lip. In the bottom half of the run a few weirs feature: one drops 1m onto a concrete slab and is awkward to portage but goes more cleanly that it would appear. Takeout river left at the bridge by the carpark.
directions: The takeout is at a large carpark by a small stone bridge that you'll reach driving east towards the river through Pontneddfechan. To get to the putin head back through the village then take the steep hill up to the open moor. Once the road flatterns out keep an eye out for a layby on the right just before a cattle grid. If you reach the houses of Ystradfellte you've gone too far. From this layby walk down the track next to the layby and keep following it downhill as it turns into a footpath to reach the river (about a km walkin). Putin at the base of a large waterfall, just before the 3m exit drop.

desc: Sister river to the Sprint, but a fair bit easier. Getting in higher up is possible, but higher water would be required as a minimum and trees tend to be more of a problem.
directions: Takeout at the recycle area of the Morrisons on the A6 just north of Kendal. Putin on river left at Patton Bridge, if there's not enough space to park, try the minor road on the other side of the river which heads off upstream.

desc: A classic waterfall run. Two of the major drops are often portaged. The first is runnable with care (shallow landing), the second looks filthy - good luck! The rest of the run is excellent grade 4 before mellowing in the last km to easier water.
directions: Takeout at the small bridge in Pontneddfechan, at the start of the "waterfall walk". To reach the putin head up the small road on river left before heading down a steep hill to the riverside picnic site at Pont Melin-Fach.

desc: A fun section, with good ledge drops and waves for beginners to practice on. Keep an eye out for the weirs, the one near the putin is boxed in.
directions: Takeout at Merthyr Mawr, just south-west of Bridgend. Putin at Ogmore Vale (on the A4061).

desc: Random urban spate boating in the middle of Geordie land. A few weirs and one 4m waterfall. You must get out before Heaton as the river disappears underground!
directions: Put in and take out wherever suits around Jesmond Park. Highest point is South Gosforth, absolutely must get out before Heaton, Armstrong bridge probably the best bet.

desc: Excellent, but challenging run: starts with a series of pool-drop rapids, then gets steeper and more continuous.
directions: Putin at Cadover bridge on the minor roads south-east of Yelverton. Takeout at Shaugh bridge, just west of the village of Shaugh Prior, or continue straight onto the section downstream.

desc: Starts with a bang, then eases to pool-drop. Takeout on river right at a beach 200m above Bickleigh Bridge (residents prefer it).
directions: Takeout at the bridge near Bickleigh village. Putin at the bridge just west of Shaugh Prior.

desc: Fantastic run: continuous grade 3 dotted with a few garder bedrock falls.
directions: Putin at Rawthey Bridge: head out of Sedburgh through Cautley along the A683, and the bridge is about 2km north of Cross Keys. Takeout on river right at the A683 bridge just north of Sedburgh, or continue onto the next section.

desc: An addition to the main Rawthey section, consists of a few weirs and one rapid of note near the end - railway falls(IV).
directions:
If you're not just running this as an add-on to the last section, then put on at Sedbergh New Bridge where there's a big lay-by and a path to the river.
Best get-out is on the Lune, 500m below the confluence where there's a bridleway on river left.

desc: Exciting but serious paddle. Watch out for the tunnel after about 4km, which you will probably want to portage on river right and need to spot early. There is a nasty weir at Bargoed at a boxed in section of the river, it is worth inspecting before getting on as you need to break out a long way above.
directions: Putin at the B4256 bridge between Pontlottyn and Rhymney. It is worth inspecting the weir in Bargoed during the shuttle: turn off the A469 down the road to Gilfach railway station, then head left down a track to a bridge over the river. Walk up the river for about 500m where you'll find the weir just upstream of a bridge. Takeout in Llanbradach, find a convenient route down to the river from estate next to the A469 bridge.

desc: After about 1km a footbridge marks the run into "Twin Bridges", a long rapid under two railway bridges. Further downstream stop on river right just after a small stone bridge to inspect Stainforth Force, a tricky 3-tier drop. Can be portaged on river right. From here down to Settle is pleasant grade 3 but watch out for 2 weirs, both a bit sketchy.
directions: Putin at Helwith Bridge, there is a picnic area on river right. Takeout on river right just after a footbridge below "Queen's Rock", the last significant rapid in Settle (about 100m below the main road bridge). Carry back over the footbridge to river left out to Kings Mill housing estate.

desc: Continuous grade 3 run, with one fall in a gorge reaching grade 4 in high water which is awkward to portage. The gorge starts just after a small footbridge, and is best inspected by clambering along the left bank: the 2m drop at the end is sticky in high water.
directions: Putin at Barkin Bridge: from Wray follow the minor road towards High Salter (marked Roeburndale West). Follwo this road to where it crosses the river. There is only space for 1 car by the bridge. Takeout on river left just below the road bridge on the east side of Wray. Alternatively continue past the confluence with the Hindburn to the carpark by the weir just to the north of Wray.

desc: A fun river, with a superb gorge section. In high water an absolute blast!
directions: Takeout at the main A4069 road bridge just south of Llangadog, or the smaller bridge 1.5km downstream. It helps if you have an OS map to find the put-in at the small bridge between Llwynfron and Twynllanan. Alternatively, for a less tree infested put-in, start your trip at Pont Aber on the A4069 for the last 1 km of the Clydach before it joins the Sawdde.

desc: Shrewsbury Weir is a playspot that comes into condition only when the Severn is very high. At lower levels it can form a dangerous stopper and should be avoided - note that the level suggested here is only an indicator that it should be running. If it looks nasty, it probably is - don't get on! The wave flushes when the river rises further.
directions: The weir is just downstream of the town centre itself. There is ample parking along Sydney Avenue - just find somewhere the water won't be start lapping at your car whilst you're strutting your stuff.

desc: Paddling near the source of the South Tyne. This spate section is small and narrow, containing several gorges and is quite continuous in nature.
directions: Drive up the Tyne head road from Garrigill, until you reach a gated track. Walk down to the river here. Get out at the bridge in Garrigill or combine with the section to Alston.

desc: A high water trip starting at grade 3 and dropping back to grade 2.
A Cumbrian classic. Small and fast with numerous bedrock falls and rapids.
directions: Takeout at the bridge just east of Burneside. To reach the putin head upstream through Garnett Bridge to the public toilets just north of Yewbarrow Hall.

desc: A quieter version of the Dart Loop. Mostly grade two, with one notable grade three after the Walkham confluence.

Decent water leads down into the gorge with a 5m waterfall shortly after the entrance. Plenty more excellent drops follow, but watch out for trees. The river eases off to grade 3/4 as the banks open out, and you pass the Tywynni confluence before taking out river right just above the bridge at Glyntawe or carrying on downstream straight onto the next section.
directions: Takeout at the A4067 bridge at Glyntawe (or better, paddle the section downstream). To reach the putin turn off the A4067 along a minor road up river left just north of Glyntawe and continue for a few km until the road comes close to the river.

desc: The classic section of the Tawe: a great run.  The grade can vary from 3+ to 5 between low and spate levels. At high levels be careful of the huge walled in hole that forms just downstream of Pen y Cae bridge. After this are a series of slides before a fun waterfall. After a final gorge the river eases before the takeout in Abercraf.
directions: Putin at the A4067 bridge at Glyntawe, and takeout somewhere in Abercraf: either at the upstream A4067 bridge, at the weir a few hundred metres downstream of this bridge (accessed via a small road down to the river near the large layby), or near the downstream A4067 bridge.

desc: Relaxing bimble with a few weirs.
A fun intro to whitewater for beginners, with a long sloping weir in the middle, and the hardest rapids (grade 2+) just before the takeout.
directions: The put-in is found by driving southwest out of Hawick and taking the first road off to the right. Just over the bridge is ample parking for 4-5 cars and a convenient (if grubby) path down to the river. To reach the takeout, head out of Hawick the other direction (try not to get confused by the one way system - you need to stay on the north side of the river until the roundabout near Sainsburys). A small road to the left off the A698 is the takeout (if you pass the caravan park you've gone too far). There is just about space for two cars here on river left, but it's a squeeze.

desc: Good beginner/intermediate wave and a couple of boxed-in holes.
directions: Approach from the South via Purley-on-Thames. Access via the footpath at the end of Mapledurham Drive.

desc: A big green (brown) fast wave that you can front surf and carve around on to your hearts content. The shape of the waves favours longer (faster) boats.
directions: The best parking spot (i.e. the one that causes least bother to locals) is the public car parks near the Trent Lock Inn. Once on the water, paddle downstream ~300m, avoid turning left onto the canal. Just after the railway bridge is the weir - its possible to paddle past the bouys on the left. Getting back you have two choices - put in above the weir and paddle upstream, which can be a challenge in high flows / wind, or paddle downstream a few hundred meters and turn left to come back along the canal cut, portaging the lock.

desc: A big wave river left, and at certain levels a hole river right that can be played on all day, each working best at different levels (once you've worked out how to get on them).
directions:
It is possible to park briefly just off the road at the canal cut, to unload, sort kit etc. There is normally ample parking just up the road in Sawley.

Put onto the cut above the flood lock and paddle a couple of hundred metres to the junction with the river. Nip past the buoys on the right, and have some fun. Getting back, simply take out, put back in on the cut on paddle back to the start.

It's also possible, with arrangement, to park at the Hartington Arms pub and walk across the field at the back to the river. But this involves a long carry and an uphill paddle to get to the wave.

desc: 2 fun gorges: the first is the grade 3/4 warm-up, the second harder grade 4/5 with some probable portages. Plenty of people have paddled the spillway at the putin, but note that this is illegal.
directions: Putin at the bottom of the spillway out of Llyn Brianne, east of Llanwrtyd Wells: follow minor roads up through Rhandirmwyn and Ystradffin. Takeout at Junction Pool, at the confluence of the Tywi with the Afon Doethie, or at the next road bridge just downstream.

desc: A superb touring run through a beautiful valley.
directions: Putin at the bridge over the river about 3km downstream from Llyn Brianne (downstream of Ystradffin). Takout at Dolauhirion: the minor road bridge just upstream of the main A40 bridge in Llandovery.

desc: Fun grade 3 run from the bottom of Aysgarth Falls. The river is more potent in the first half until Redmire force, which in higher water can reach grade 5, so inspection may be necessary.
directions: Park in the National Trust carpark and follow the footpath to putin just below the falls. Egress at the main road bridge in Wensley.

desc: Bouncy grade 2/3 run at decent levels. Watch out for 3 separate weirs on the way down.
directions: Takeout in Brecon in the carpark on the upstream outskirts just above a weir. Putin in Sennybridge itself (take the turn towards the barracks and stay right along the outside to park by the river), or at the small bridge just upstream of Sennybridge leading to Pantsgallog.

desc: Combined with the section below is the classic Usk paddle. An excellent play-run when in flood, still a good paddle at low levels. Highlight is Mill Falls, a fun blast in the middle. Takeout on river left at the bridge or continue downstream.
directions: Putin at the bridge on the minor road off the A40 heading towards Talybont-on-Usk. Parking is a bit tight as you have to just tuck the car into the roadside on the river-right side of the bridge. A stile leads into the field on upstream river-right from which you can access the river just above the bridge. Takeout at Llangynidr bridge or continue straight onto the next section which has probably the best whitewater. Parking at Llangynidr is also slightly tricky, you will have to head up the hill in either direction from the bridge and park in the village or on the verge.

desc: A fun grade 2+ run with one grade 3 drop. The weir just below the dam is a good playhole if the water isn't too high.
directions: Make your way along the minor roads to Lake Vyrnwy dam and putin from the carpark at its base. Takeout at the B4395 bridge at Pont LLogel, or continue onto the next section.

desc: The best of the Vyrnwy. Pleasant grade 2/3 down to the bridge at Dolanog is shortly followed by a nasty weir. Below, the walls close in as you enter the fun grade 3/4 (depending on levels) Dolanog gorge. Inspect as necessary from the footpath on river right. Easier water leads down to the takeout at Pontrobert.
directions: Putin at the B4395 bridge at Llogel, or paddle the section above down from the dam itself. Takeout in Pontrobert on river left 50m upstream of the bridge through a stile out to the road.

desc: A few gd3 drops lead into a scenic gd1/2 meander past Blairquan Castle, followed by the gd3 Tranew Gorge.
directions: Putin at the B741 bridge just west of Straiton. Takeout at the minor road bridge just south of Kirkmichael.

desc: A relaxed start, and remains max grade 4 for the first 5km until Palgowan Bridge (an alternative option for the putin). Picks up once the banks become wooded about a km below Palgowan Bridge, with several grade 5 drops including the Falls of Minnoch and the "Black Linn". Takeout after or just before Dog Leg Falls which is just below Stroan Bridge.
directions: Takeout at the Glen Trool Visitor Centre at Stroan Bridge, which is also a good place to check the levels and admire Dog Leg Falls. To reach the putin head north along the minor road: either get on at Palgowan Bridge (for a short grade 5 run), or continue up to the picnic site for the full 10km section. It is also possible to continue down onto the Water of Trool to Borgan Bridge (an extra 5km of grade 3/4).

desc: Fairly continuous grade two, with the odd bit of three, an occasional surf wave and a weir above Wolsingham.
directions: Put in from the South bank of the ford at Stanhope. Get out at Hamsterly road bridge in Wolsingham, with parking at the station.

desc: A pleasant grade 2 touring paddle, dotted with lots of weirs and a notable playwave.
directions: Putin in the centre of the village of Clapham, or 3.5km downstream at the bridge at Clapham station (a couple of beck join in between, so the the station putin may be better when low). Takeout on river left just below the bridge at Hornby.

desc: Lovely small tree lined gorge until Lee Bridge, where the river passes over a small weir. Below this the river widens out and increases in volume with the addition of several small tribs. Whilst the river is best saved for in medium-high water, it becomes a terrifyingly relentless tree avoidance mission in spate.
directions: From the takeout between the confluence of the two rivers at Abbeystead drive North East, taking a left turn down the hill to pass over the river at Lee Bridge where you can hop out to inspect the weir below. Turn right and drive up the river right bank. Parking is minimal, except for a large grassy area about 500m south of Tarnbrook itself. This misses out a small weir under the bridge at Ouzel Thorn, but saves hassle!

desc: From the confluence of the Tarnbrook and Marshaw Wyre's the river flows through a flat overgrown section of river into Abbeystead reservoir. The dam is yet to see a descent, for good reason, portage on the left and put back in below a small foot bridge. Two small weirs of note break up the easier water on the way down to Dolphinholme. The river continues at the same grade down at least as far as Cleveley Bridge, but this is into fishing territory, so expect hassle!

directions: If wanting to avoid Blachford Manor, you can miss the upper section and put in at Langham Bridge. There's not much in the way of parking spaces at either put-in or the take-out.

desc: A spate run down the Diliw into the Ystwyth, full of boulder gardens and boulder-choked drops.
directions: Takeout at the bridge in Cwmystwyth. To reach the putin on tarmac you'll need to loop round through Llangurig and head down a small road off the A44 through Glangwy. Much shorter is to head directly upstream from Cwmystwyth and then take a rough track up the Diliw at Blaenycwm (this would be tough without a 4x4). It is also possible to putin on the upper Ystwyth by by continuing upstream along the road from Blaenycwm, or just putin at the Diliw confluence and avoid all the faff!

desc: Decent run, watch out for the broken dam. The gorge below the takeout looks horrendous and makes a better gorge walk than paddle.
directions: Putin at the bridge at Cwmystwyth, and takeout at the bridge in Pont-rhyd-y-groes.
